reviewText:
One of the best PC RPG's ever!


Introduction - I would have to start this by saying that first off this game is absolutely massive. There is simply put no other way to describe it in one word. The original Morrowind was my favorite Action Role Playing Game of all time so this upgrade ranks even higher on my list. The Morrowind legacy Grows.

Gameplay - This is where The original Morrwind really shines, and Game of the Year edition improves on an already great formula. When you first begin the game you get to start by choosing one of ten races which include everything from the traditional humans, orcs and elves, to the more fantasy like races of the cat like Kajiit people, and the lizard like Argonians. From there you proceed to totally customize everything about your character, including looks, class birth sign, and much more. Each different class and attribute, has a large effect on the game, so playing as an elf mage is completely different than playing as an elf thief, or assassin. The birth signs also come with their own special powers, and weakness's as well so each one is worth trying at least once.

When you're finally into the game things start off a bit slow. You run a couple of errands, collect a few stray items as the game walks you through the first little bit, but you soon realize that there is a freedom here that no other game has managed to get just right. Want that piece of armor you see lying there on someone's shelf? Grab it. Want that cool looking sword you see a guard carrying kill him and take it, but be prepared for consequences.
Bethesda went to such great detail on this aspect, that almost every item in the game can be interacted with with great freedom. You can spend hours at a time simply decorating a house you've made your home base, and all items aren't simply decoration. Books are fully readable, herbs can be mixed into potions, crates, bags, and shelves can all be used for storage. Beds can be slept in, candles and lanterns can be placed in your home to light it, or carried along to light dark areas.
As far as character development, it's extraordinary, and a bit overwhelming at the same time. Every single action you take has the possibility of increasing one or more skills. Even something so simple as walking or swimming will lead to a faster stronger character in the end. There are nearly limitless combinations in ways to grow your character, so long as you remember every thing you do affects you in some way.
Fighting at first is a bit difficult until you increase in some skills a bit, but with practice you will soon be swinging axes, and casting spells with the best.
There is also an option for a third person view if the first person is not your thing, but keep in mind that fighting is a bit more difficult like this because aiming becomes harder.

Story- The story in Morrowind was great, in the game of the Year it simply gets better with two completely new areas to explore, the addition of the Werewolf, and lots more surprises that I won't speak of here. Needless to say it the Story in Game of the Year is greatly improved.

Graphics/Sound - My only real complaint about the first Morrowind was the choppiness in the frame rate, and the awkward way in which it made characters move. Thankfully this has been greatly improved. Characters, and NPCs have a much more fluid look, and less robot-like appearance now. Another improvement is that there is much less fog now. Before it was used to cover pop-in, but now for the most part it is used to convey mood rather than cover up for the programmers.
The sound and music are both fantastic. Each race has unique grunts groans, and dialect, they also speak with accents that seem proper for their race. The music has always been a favorite of mine in morrowind, and Game of the Year is no exception. It has that special way of making you feel as though you are really part of something special.

Play Time/Replayability -This is really a harder one to judge. The play time simply put is as long as you want it to be. As far as a straight walkthrough you could spend anywhere from fifty hours to one hundred plus hours, depending on how many side quest you choose to do, and the rate at which you choose to develop your character.
Replayability is without a doubt one of Game of the Years best features. As stated earlier each of the Races are completely unique, with there own strengths and weaknesses, add to that all the different classes, the birth signs, literally thousands of different combinations of ways to get through the game, and you have a mighty big game. That's not even mentioning the completely new quest that were added in the expansion.

Final Recommendation -In conclusion I full-heartedly recommend anyone that has a PC, and even the slightest love of Role Playing Games pick Up this game. It will keep you immersed in it's world for no doubt hours at the time, and at only thirty bucks, you get a lot of added content over the original. I say that Morrowinds world is completely magic, and that's what games are supposed to be.

reviewText:
Have you played skyrim before this? Did you enjoy the hell out of it? This game may be too old school for you, purchase at your own risk. Did you play this before you played oblivion or Skyrim? What are you reading reviews for!? You should either have the game already or be buying it right now!

To summarize what I love about this game
- The setting
- Navigation
- Interesting quests and events
- Ability to become insanely OP
- Enemies that don't scale to your level

The island of Vvardenfell remains my favourite landscape. Sure the graphics are dated. But, I still recall my astonishment as I exited the boat for the first time. The alien creatures, silt striders, Kwama, nix hounds and those damned cliff racers. The giant mushrooms, sandstorms and blizzards set the environment apart from other sandbox settings. Subtle animations such as your character shielding their face from the sand being tossed about in the storm bring the world to life.

Questing in this game is quite different from modern rpg and sandbox games. No quest markers exist, at all. Your source of directions are the locals and those you provide you with the quests. Luckily your journal will log all conversations related to quests and topics. Need to remember how to get to Balmora? Open your journal and search under B, any important conversations about the place will be recalled for you to reread.

I don't want to spoil the magic of this event just in case someone reads this, decides to purchase the game and is yet to experience it. But it is just north of Seyda Neen, along the path through the swamp. As another example, further of the track near Seyda Neen, the body of an Imperial tax collector can be found. Still with all his money. What do you do? that is your choice. Tell the guards? Keep the money for yourself? Track down the murderer? No quest markers means that the quest ends when you want it to (to a degree). Of course the true ending of this quest is to track down the murderer, but there is nothing to stop you from just looting the corpse and forgetting about the whole incident.

I'll sum this point up quickly. Scrolls of Icarian Flight Fortify your acrobatics by 1,000 points, making your jump send you flying into the clouds. Without a levitate or slowfall spell the landing will kill you. These are a joke item. But you get the picture.

Finally, the leveling in this game. This is not like modern elder scrolls games. In both Oblivion and Skyrim enemies would scale to your level. However, in Morrowind this does not occur. Early days exploring are best spent cautiously, some enemies will one hit you, should you get too comfortable exploring a Dwemer ruin.

I should also mention combat. This could be a turn off for some. The best way to explain it is that everything is determined by die rolls. Trying to hack at a creature with your sword? What is your skill with a blade? Do you have enough stamina for the swing? What is the targets dexterity? This is all taken into account as you try to hit a target. So some of your attacks will appear to pass through the enemy, missing for no reason.

So do I recommend this game? Yes, Absolutely. This game is a must buy (in my opinion) for any fan of rpgs. I'd like to think that anyone who's a fan of the elder scrolls series has played this game. I fear many may call it dated, and give the game a miss. There is much to appreciate in this game. If the animation and graphics are an issue for you there is an overhaul mod pack which adds much to the game, even at the cost to some of the original feel. But you can tweak it to be more faithful to the vanilla game.

reviewText:
As a later TES fan, you may find it hard to believe that someone who actually started with Skyrim has found Morrowind to be their favorite installment in the series. But the thing is, Morrowind has a particular charm to it, despite it being over eleven years old. There are several things I'd like to discuss about Morrowind and why you should ultimately buy it, whether you're new to the TES series, or are a die-hard fan screaming for nostalgia.

I'd like to create some points with Morrowind discussing its values:

1. Presentation
2. Gameplay
3. Overall

Ready? Let's begin.

Point One: Presentation.

At first glance, Morrowind shows its age with the early Embryo engine with skeletal animation, and an average of 800 x 600 display. Also noticable is how NPC's stay within a general area without eating, drinking, or sleeping (sounds like a serious insomnia epidemic, no?). But besides that, there's nothing really flawed about the graphics, and it's actually reminiscent of Oblivion's. This gives Morrowind a sense of familiarity to begin with. You start off the game with a cinematic intro, as you awaken on an Imperial prison ship that has docked on an Imperial colony, Seyda Neen. From there, you enter your name, choose your race, and once you enter the Commision Office, you are asked to choose your birthsign, favored attributes, and class. From there on, you are asked to deliver a message to a man named Caius, and thus your quest begins. Or at least, the main quest begins. Like other TES games, what you do there on out is up to you. Fight monsters and bandits, loot tombs and ruins, join guilds and political factions, basically what you'd expect from an open-world RPG. That said, the island of Vvardenfell is wonderful, given you can see it, with the render distance and all. Cities aren't closed in separate maps like they were in Oblivion and Skyrim, and the geography is very immersive as you walk around, looking for your objective or simply looking for a dungeon to pillage. As you walk around Vvardenfell, you will encounter strange creatures, such as the Nix-Hound, the Alit, the Netches, and the infamous Cliff Racer. Imagination was really put into these monsters, and some of them won't be so easy to kill. As for the islands residents, Vvardenfell is home to the Dunmer, the ash-skined elves you've seen in the later or earlier installments. Their culture is reminiscent to that of Asian and some tribal cultures, as they may live in the shells of ancient arthropods, adobe buildings, giant mushrooms, and nomadic tents. You will also find your typical Imperial stone structures, things you may yawn about. The in-game literature in Morrowind is very well-written, providing fictional stories to amuse you with, informative tips about the local governments, cities, and religion, and even books that hint on certain gameplay aspects such as vampirism. It truly is something to see the thought lingers in your head.

Point Two: Gameplay

As for perhaps the most important aspect of any game, the gameplay element in Morrowind is quite different from the later installments ( and definitly Arena, but we aren't comparing.) The game offers a wide variety of skills to use, with various weapon types, from typical swords and warhammers, to spears and throwing stars, to crossbows and staves. There are also a wide variety of spells to use, from your average destruction and restoration spells, to teleportation, and even flying spells. Filed Soul Gems can be used on epuipment to enchant them, and an alchemy set can be used with flora, fauna, and even raw minerals to brew potions and poisons. Dialouge with NPCs is somewhat different, though, as they will communicate with text-based responses to the selected topic, and there are many things to talk about with NPCs. The thing about dialouge is despite these many topics, what they say is usually the same as everybody else. Copy-pasted, in fact, thus rendering many NPC void of real personality, unlike Oblivion and Skyrim. As for conflict with enemies, you may either hate it or simply don't care, as it works more like D&D role-playing games. Based on your skil with a certain weapon type, or the Agility attribute itself, you may miss an enemy point-blank while they take crackshots at you (though still able to miss.). Magic works similarly, as using less skilled magic type while tired out will usually result in failure to cast the spell. Aside from those questionable gameplay elements, however, there's still plenty to be had with Morrowind. You can't simply fast travel from the map so you could skip treking all the way to a destination, but rather you use public transportation, teleportation spells, and spells to increase your speed to move around Vvardenfell. Personally, this gave Morrowind a really huge look at the world map, even though it's only 10 square miles + 2-3 from the Bloodmoon expansion and about an additional one from Tribunal, compared to Cyrodill and Skyrim (16 square miles each) or even The Iilic Bay from Daggerfall, with a whopping 480,000 sqare miles (randomly generated though). Plus, you really got to know the geogrophy of Vvardenfell, as the game references landmarks and cities to help you navigate the world, all written in your little journal. Speaking of which, the journal system is probably the closest thing you'll have for a friend in this game ( besides Ahnassi, of course ). Quests and Topics are recorded on your journal with every indication. Viewing your journal is always very helpful if you've been sidetracked from looting dungeons or completing other side quests. That's not to say it isn't flawed, of course. Some quests give really bad direction and can be sometimes misleading. If you don't believe me, join House Redoran. This was really compensated in later installments with a quest marker, as a mere convinence. But don't let the gameplay issues deter you from purchasing this amazing title. Overall, the game function very well and even a late audience can find enjoyment out of it.

Point Three: Overall

Many thing can be said about Morrowind to criticize it. The fact that NPCs had nearly no personality at all, a cumbersome combat and magic system, and even some broken quests do hurt Morrowind a little bit. But despite these cons, Morrowind is uplifted with many pros. Its lore will fascinate you, the landscape will amaze you, and your impact on the game world will really matter here. You truly can be what you want, whether that be a noble knight, a malevolent mage, an infamous assassin, or a troublesome thief, Morrowind can provide.

I stole his icarus scrolls and his sick banana wizard outfit, then headed down the road through the 2spooky4me forest.  In this forest, I walked with swag, fought some skribs (heh heh... skrubs), and learned that you miss less if you use a smaller sword (wtf).

So I made it to Balmora.  Having learned of the <cough> excellent combat system in Morrowind, I went to the Mage Guild hoping to learn some good spells so I didn't have to deal with melee combat anymore.  Enemies could dodge and I couldn't, plus my Banana Wizard costume didn't have much armor.  On my first assignment for the mage guild, after I was done laughing at the... ahem, well-animated... khajit walking animations, I was sent on a noble and dangerous quest of... fetching mushrooms.  This is some Elder Scrolls Online ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, I didn't sign up for AHEM

So anyway, I made it to the 2spooky4me swamp.  I stole some mushrooms, then took a nap.  When I woke up, a Dark Brotherhood guy came after me.  I just knew he was after my mushrooms, which he wanted to make weed out of.  I ♥♥♥♥♥slapped him with the sword and swung it a million times for 1000000x1 damage.  After he had been beaten to death with a glorified dinner fork, I stole his armor set and left.

On my return, I was gladly welcomed with-- another fetch quest.  But wait, this time it's flowers!  NO.

I tried to flip the table.  Sadly, there's no physics-grab button like in Oblivion and Fallout 3, so the table was bolted to the floor as was every item until you picked it up.  I walked out as if I had flipped the table.

Despite my hatred of the combat system, I go to the fighter's guild.  I'm sent right to the house next door to fight some baddies, but before I go I'm given full access to their arsenal.

So yes, this game taught me an important life lesson.  Magic is for sissy manchildren.  FIGHTERS FTW

reviewText:
I've played this more before it was available on Steam.  The only reason I ended up with a Steam Copy was that I bought the Anthology.

This is the best Elder Scrolls game hands down.  You can levitate, the continent is huge, everything is a lot more freeform than Oblivion and Skyrim.  If you're worried about the 2003 graphics, just download the Morrowind Graphics and Sound Overhaul mod pack and get your game looking better.  There's a ton more factions, more lore, more spells.  I would gladly trade voiced characters in the next installment for a deeper and more immersive experience like this is.

The biggest gripe a lot of people have is the old dice system combat.  Every swing of a sword, cast of a spell, and shot of a bow is based on a roll to determine if it's successful.  It's only an issue at the beginning of the game, as your skills increase the dice roll will become less of an issue.

If it's ever on sale, pick it up and give it a shot.

reviewText:
This is it: the greatest Elder Scrolls game ever.

Ok, it doesn't look to great by today's standards (but there are TONS of mods to improve the graphics), and the combat system is pretty clumsy (although I love it) but the gameplay, the exploring, the freedom, and all the things you can do make this a game you'll gladly sink hundreds or thousands of hours into.  There's a lot more depth to this game than any of the Elder Scrolls games that have come since.

I've probably spent a thousand hours playing Morrowind, and I still feel like I haven't seen it all (I haven't even spent much time on the two expansions).  In 2002 when Morrowind first came out on PC and Xbox, it was my life.  I loved the game so much I bought it for both systems.  My friends saw me playing it and several of them became addicts as well.  I was never turned off by the slow start or the difficulty in using your low level skills.  In fact, that was part of the fun for me - watching my character grow from someone who could hardly do ANYTHING in this world to a god-like juggernaut that could do ANYTHING in this world.  It's so satisfying, and much more satisfying than the character growth in any other game I've ever played, Elder Scrolls or not.

The spell creation system, which is sadly missing from newer Elder Scroll games, is so fun to play around with.  If you have the skill and money you can mix ANY of the spells together for some fun effects.  And there are a LOT more spells in this game.  Some are a little pointless (I've never figured out the point of the Sound" spell) but some are tons of fun.  Levitate is a blast.  See something up high you can't get to?  Just Levitate up to it!  And the Jump/Slow Fall combo of spells is great.  You can do an uber-powerful jump

reviewText:
I could truly go into detail about this game, but for now, I'll mostly just say it's a flawed gem or even a masterpiece depending on your opinion.

The game has some very archaic features such as dice rolls determining your ability to hit enemies which means you can miss even if you have a high skill with the weapon, but it's not as bad as some people make it out to be and you just have to learn to cope with it. However, this is a considerably unforgiving game overall.

You have to be careful not to go off the beaten path too much as enemies don't scale in level the way they do in this game's successors. There are also diseases which can give nasty effects to your character such as debuffs potentially lasting until the disease is cured though it can easily be done with potions that you should always have on you.

You also need to be sure you make good choices when it comes to creating your character so you can maximize your chances of survival and killing potential. It's probably best to select a predesigned class or even look online to get an idea of building your character effectively. This does NOT mean you have to follow them exactly and use cookie-cutter builds to succeed. They're just general rules of thumb which you can better understand with. This way you won't go around missing every swing and dying instantly to enemies.

Quests take more attention than they do in successors because there's no compass pointing you to your objectives meaning you must read your journal to see the directions there which aren't always 100% accurate. While this can be confusing and you may just not enjoy it, it serves to better immerse you into the experience and encourage you to explore the surrounding areas of the quests.

The last possibly negative things I'd like to mention are the various exploits and bugs. You should definitely install the fan made patches, that you can find online for free which should fix the majority of the bugs that would otherwise make it a terribly glitchy experience. As far as exploits, these can be avoided if you choose to and play the game normally, but from what I've heard, alchemy can really unbalance the game with things like flying above enemies and shooting them and buffing up to near invisibility. However, you might find this to be a fun aspect of the game.

There are many other things to learn that I didn't cover like this such as disposition and fatigue so I'd encourage anyone to look up some information to guide you a bit where a manual might have if you had a physical copy. This won't take anything from the experience (depending on where you look), unless you're the type who likes to go into a game and figure everything out the hard way, and it will probably prevent a lot of frustration for a beginner.

To talk about the good, I'm sure you could easily look online to find a cult following gushing about this game, but from my own experience, the reason I enjoy this the most in the series is it's complexity, depth, and thematically alien feeling. You can look up what makes this game comparatively deeper and complex than the others with things like each individual weapon type being a skill and how the many factions interact with you and each other, but I just want to mention the world.

Morrowind is a very strange place compared to the other games and real life in general. The environment includes ashlands which are essentially barren shadows of past volcanic eruptions that have caused dry, dusty terrain with calderas mostly providing the only form of pass through the many impassable (without flying) mountains. There's also the 'West Gash Region' which is hard to describe, but definitely unusual. There are other places more familiar like the 'Bitter Coast' being swampland, more that I can't name that are grasslands, beach, shallow waterered areas with stones and land sticking up from it with giant thorn trees where flying wizards reside, a lake area with different plantation grounds where slaves work. Most of the biomes contain giant mushrooms which act as trees. There's even an island in the Northwest, provided in one of the expansions that come with this version where there are traditional forests, ice areas and snowy places. So Morrowind cetainly has the most various environments of the last three Elder Scrolls.

The native npcs themselves where insect armor, ride giant insects to other areas, use large reptiles to serve as mules, have a strange religion featuring many of their own gods not seen in the other games, have cities on water and shun any 'outlanders'. There are also ash dwellers who live in tribes that celebrate the banned god Nerevar who acts as a central plot - point to the story.

The story is compelling enough, but it's the presentation that makes it great. You don't know a lot of what's going on when you first get to Morrowind and you only find out through books, npcs who are reluctant to inform you, and other npcs who help further the plot along. It's a very mysterious game.

Simply put, this game demands a lot from you, but it's extremely satisfying when you succeed and win the main quest, not to mention all the side quests and definitely rewards you for being invested in the story and lore which are truly deserving of the word 'fantasy'.

reviewText:
The Elder Scrolls series: Oblivion and Online are ok, Skyrim is pretty good, but THIS game is my RPG codifier.

Slower, quieter, more subtle than it's succesors, you will find no demons falling out of the sky or dragons setting towns aflame in Morrowind. Instead, the land is threatened by a slowly encroaching volcanic wasteland, a disease spreading amongst the populace, and plots, upheaval, and assasinations amongst the ruling and religious bodies. There will be no setpiece battles in Morrowind; your enemies lurk in the darkest corners of the world and are content to wait for you there and work their plots from afar.

It is a genuinely different and fascinating story.

reviewText:
I have been playing The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind Game of the Year Edition for years now albeit a bit on and off. I predominantly spent my time playing it on the Xbox.

Some say that it is a bit dated on the graphics front but you have to remember that this game is 12 years old. Despite this, however, I think as far as the graphics and the general game play goes it was way ahead of it's time.

With Morrowind you really don't start with much and you really don't get a lot of help. The sheer fact that you have to work hard to get other characters in the game to like you enough to actually tell you anything worthwhile is gripping.

You can join a whole host of different factions and this helps to build your character. As some factions do not like each other you can end up being slightly more disliked by one faction or race than another.

Ultimately the games main story line never changes but the multitude of side quests is mind boggling and if you can't even be bothered with those you can spend an age just running around collecting valuable and rare items and increasing your stats to almost godly levels

The animals: If you think that Dragons are bad my goodness you haven't met a Cliff Racer
(Be mega wary of the diseased or blighted ones especially if you are a weaker character)

Favourite 'Easter Egg': It has to be the Mudcrab Merchant. If you find this little guy make sure you have a Mark and Recall spell so you can find him again as he is situated on a tiny island in the middle of no-where. He is the richest merchant in the entire game

Little tip: Listen to the music. The music is set to warn you of any impending danger. If you are being attacked it will change quickly, if you are going to be it will be more subtle (But don't be fooled sometimes the game likes to play the first few notes of the attack sequence music before launching into the normal calm outdoors music)

I did write a slightly longer review originally but couldn't fit it all in. If you want that then let me know

reviewText:
Ahh Morrowind is so close to home. You play as The Nerevarine as prophesied to defeat the Dagoth Ur, who have tapped into the power of an artefact known as the Heart of Lorkhan in a bid to exert control over the inhabitants of Morrowind. This game is set predominantly on the island of Vvardenfell, just off the coast of Stonefall, in northern Morrowind.

Any hardcore Elder Scrolls fan would instantly feel at home with the rich characterisation, role-playing elements, visual details, soundtrack and the quintessential open-world environment. It is still the best of all the Elder Scrolls games, because of the magnitude of the game for its time and the back-to-basics approach in role-playing - tremendous storyline, realistic characterisation, interaction and progression.

There are weaknesses to this game however, the UI is not particularly helpful to meta-gamers (c.f. Oblivion min-maxing), the journal system whilst improved in the expansion, is still rather cumbersome to navigate, the inherent 'block' in combat can be difficult to get used to for some, as is the one-mouse-button attack and finally the graphics - this is a 2002 game, but thankfully the modding community has made graphic enhancement addons that could be easily installed and used with the game.

Overall, this game is a gem.

reviewText: Unlike the newer two iterations of the Elder Scrolls, Morrowind is a role-playing game, not an action adventure. Player choice and character skill is what matters. In Skyrim and Oblivion, progress in the game is controlled by point-and-click combat and mini games where player skill is what matters. In Morrowind, the skill of a character is what matters, with hidden dice rolls and comparisons controlling successes and failures.\nSome will complain that the combat is clunky, and that they hate missing a rat 20 times and dying as a result. But if you have a skill of 5 in short blade, why are you using a dagger? Building or picking a class, allocating attribute points correctly, and choosing a logical strategy for your character is what makes this game so much different from Skyrim, where anyone can cast spells, swing swords, and sneak with extreme proficiency.\nBy making you start off small, learn and mold your character's strengths and weaknesses, and lick the boots of every NPC around you, Morrowind lets you grow from a worthless, scummy, ex-con n'wah to the all powerful, well respected Nerevar Incarnate.

reviewText:
Morrowind is a pinnacle in the Elder Scrolls series, it was a massive advancement on Daggerfall, with it's incorporation of proper 3D, and benefited from the development of the smaller gaming region by focusing on the island of Vvardenfell.
In typical Elder Scrolls style the primary narrative is fairly formulaic revolving around the prophecy of the Nerevarine, but where it deviates is the impact that this has not only on the religious aspects of the world, a part of prophecy that is not often explored in fantasy narratives but also on the wider political spectrum of Tamriel, what if Akulakhan had truly awoken?
Morrowind more than its sequels allowed players to truly delve into the depths and world building of the Elder Scrolls universe, yet still offered a decent leveling system, combined with it's simplistic conflict mechanics. On this level, as a game to be interacted with Morrowind required much improvement, partially done by modders that covered over and developed the game in directions the smaller group of original developers would never have managed.

Morrowind is still an excellent game if you want to truly explore a fantasy environment that is utterly unique, and become immersed and explore an alien world, with skills and abilities that far surpass those offered to players in earlier and later Elder Scrolls games. Although not as technically accomplished as its sequels, Morrowind more than excels them in its vibrant and diverse world.

reviewText:
The Elder Scrolls lll: Morrowind is acknowledged by many TES fans as the best game in the series. It has a few features which other Elder Scrolls games failed to accomplish. The ability to kill every single npc in the game you want, regardless if it's part of a quest or not; The lack of quest markers and instead having to rely on directions and your common sense; The privilege of taking any house you want and call it your own. Not only that: the world feels completely different. It's not your average fantasy game filled with unicorns and dragons, instead the game throws more unique creatures at you: Kwama's, Nix-Hound's, Netches, Ogrim's, Kagouti just to name a few.

Combat
Some people hate it. Others love it. It depends on how you look at it. While in combat hitting someone does not necessarily mean it actually hits. Lots of factors play a role in this, such as the amount of stamina you have, how skilled you are in the weapon category (daggers, spears, longswords etc) and your agility attribute. If these parameters are high enough the game makes it count as a hit. The more you use a weapon in a certain category the more skilled you will become and thus essentially making you hit your target more often. This however also means you cannot easily switch from weapon to weapon. If your skill in daggers is 90 and you found an axe which does approximately 10 more damage than your current weapon it might be a better idea to stick with your dagger and move on as your low skill in axes might put you at a disadvantage.

Exploration
Exploring is extremely rewarding. There's always something cool and new to discover such as finding a wood elf plummeting to his death who carries the infamous scrolls of icarian flight which allows you to jump tremendous distances. Or who could have known the legendary dragon bone cuirass is locked away in a closet on a random island in the middle of nowhere? You will never know what treasures and garbage a cave has hidden.

Quests
As mentioned above there are no quest markers present in Morrowind. Instead you will need to rely on your brain and directions given by npc's. Quest items can also be freely sold to any merchant even though this may mean permanently breaking the entire quest once the merchant has stocked up on different wares.

reviewText: Morrowind is something special, something different. Imagine three times the quests and content of Skyrim compressed into one small island, with so much lore and depth that you can lose yourself for hours and hours. Sure, it isn't a really pretty game, but slap MGSO on it and you've got an astonishingly good looking game to complement it's other aspects. You see, in Skyrim you find out you are dragonborn... cool! Yes, that means you get to incinerate people, make them fly off of cliffs etc. In Morrowind though, you start off as almost weaker than mudcrabs, but become a GOD by the end of the game, quite literally. Feel like flying around the whole map without even needing console commands? Go ahead. Want to jump like a super hero from Seyda Neen to Balmora? Do it! Kill the end game boss in one hit? Yes, you can do that. The possibilities are endless, and even though all of the above is true, that doesn't mean you're the strongest thing around, there are still monsters that are quite dangerous even in the late game, see what's different between newer entries and Morrowind? Yes, FREEDOM, to become whatever you like. Now, Morrowind isn't perfect, but it's probably the best game in the series. These days, even though it has aged well enough, it can be very difficult to get into, and since you are thrown instantly into a massive world with only a small dagger, quite confusing. But don't give up. Keep playing, and you could turn your 3 hours of frustration into your 300 hour playthrough of the best game experience you've ever had.\n\nSo I don't think I need to tell you how much I recommend this game. But as I said, it's not without flaws, it's simply that the strong points make it so amazing that you won't need to worry about the flaws. I think there is something in this game for everyone, and it's an experience that can't be missed. Grab it in the christmas sale (it's almost always on sale then), grab MGSO, also known as Morrowind Graphics and Sound Overhaul, and make sure your body is ready for one of the best PC games ever made. Have fun!

When I got this game, I thought it was terrible. I thought that my game was bugged because I was getting point blank misses. Now, however, this is my favorite game of all time. Though it was a hard start, I can tell you why this game is so amazing.
You start the game extremely underpowered, with a set of terrible clothes, a dagger, 87 gold and, if you are smart. some extra trinkets to sell and a terrible lockpick.
I would also like to note that this is a hardcore RPG with a few action concepts, such as real time combat. However, much of the game is based on your character's skill, not your skill. So, if you have a bad short blade skill, you will get at least 9 out of 10 hits as a miss. In fact, I would even argue that this game and skyrim (I have played both) can be classified into different subgenres because of the differences.
Later in the game, it is the opposite of the beginning. You become an unbeatable god. It is the greatest feeling I have ever had in a game. This is why I reccomend this game.

reviewText:
I think a video game succeeds when it can immserse its players into its world.

Morrowind does that, and it does it great.
I've found myself lost within Morrowind's world several times, exploring every nook and cranny of Vvardenfell, talking to every NPC I can, learning more about Vvardenfell and its lore, and of course, killing monsters!

The story in this game for me is much better than the story in Oblivion or Skyrim, to sum it up you're POSSIBLY the reincarnate of the badass Lord Nerevar and you are on a quest to save Morrowind from the ash blight storms. (and Dagoth Ur, remember that place from Arena?)

It's amazing how you start as such a lowly and disgusting outlander, then you start to hone your abilities and stay true to who you're loyal to, and then you have the power to do anything you want! Then you're an invincible demi-god with 1000 acrobatics EASILY jumping across and around the whole map. The game for me is about the freedom to do anything, anywhere. The only limitations are the hardware and the engine, so go frickin' nuts.

Though the game DOES have its flaws.
-  RNG based combat (dice rolls) Excusable though, seeing how this is an RPG. Just seems odd to have RNG based combat in a game like this though.
-  Uninteresting NPCs and boring towns
-  Bugs.. Every (especially Bethesda) game has these though.

Regarding the combat, I don't think combat has ever been good in an Elder Scroll game, especially the swing your mouse at the enemy type of combat in Arena in Daggerfall. The combat is this game fortunately doesn't depend on swinging your mouse like a madman (and RNG!).. but instead is dependent on dice rolls(same thing). The game takes every possible factor from how much fatigue you have to how far your enemy to your agility to your weapon skills is to determine whether you'll hit or miss. Your skill with a weapon also determines your chance to hit with that type of weapon, for example, you're more likely to hit enemies with Spear 100 then Spear 25 while using a spear.

Despite its minor and/or major flaws, these can be fixed, and Morrowind still remains as a masterpiece that can never be replicated, which is why people are STILL playing the game in 2014, and why I'll still be playing in 2015.

reviewText:
10/10
I have played this game so many times over and each time I find something new to be intrigued by!
Morrowind, while pretty old, is incredibly detailed and can be a challenging game. I've played oblivion, skyrim, and online too, and I still always come back to play Morrowind.
To get a good idea of the level of detail and vastness of the game, have a look at the Morrowind UESP Wiki. I loved browsing all the stuff I didn't yet know about on that wiki.

I'll put the game in perspective though... It's old, looks old, feels old. It can be boring and slow at times, and very hard. You may die a lot at first as your levels are crap, you may keep inflicting no damage hit after hit in combat untill you get your levels up. Walking will take ages and you will probably get lost and not be able to find your destination. BUT if you can push your way through the hardships at first and get use to the game and the world of Morrowind, then you will find some very challenging and enjoyable rpg game play! As you get the hang of the game, you will also love that the learning and discovering does not stop there! You will keep finding new and awesome things!!! Have a look at my positives list for why I loved the game and what it's main attraction points are.

Anyway, positives and negatives!!!
Positives:
-Extremely rich detail in all key game areas! Loads of different armour types(and I recon the old quality graphics makes everything look really detailed and realistic due to a more rough/worn look). Loads of different weapon types, there are spears, staffs, throwing knives, even ninja stars!!! Loads of unique items. A lot more guilds/factions than the other TES games, there is fighters, mages, thieves, imperial legion, imperial cult, east empire trading company, morag tong, tribunal temple, aundae/berne/quarra clan, ashlander tribes, and all the Great Houses of Morrowind(Hlaalu, Redoran, and Telvanni).
-Great sound track! Classic Elder Scrolls amazing music.
-Good voice actors(lol oblivion), the unique and outlandish voices for some of the cool characters/races really serve to immerse you in the game. If it bothers you though, there is a narrow range of different voices...
-Awesome spells!!! There are levitation spells for goodness sake!!
-Ban Hammer item :D
-Detailed quests/game information/history.
-Good books, (The Lusty Argonian Maid).    ;)
-Dungeons and ruins and tombs and ship wrecks and dwemmer ruins and forts and caves and bandit camps and bandit hideouts and tons of cool locations EVERYWHERE! You will never run out of places to explore!
-Some very uniqe scenery/settings in Morrowind. The tree/plant/mushroom buildings of the Telvanni people are awesome!
-Great loot everywhere, hidden.
-Also, just the level of detail put into the game by the developers is great. Rarely will you have a 'boring' quest or dungeon, there is often cool little features put in, or cool background stories that serve no purpose but to intrigue! I can remember many occasions where I have gone into a cave or such and been really challenged with actually navigating it, the path to the objective/destination can be hidden really well.
-I have to emphasise the point of amazing in game detail! xD I just loved how there was so much to do and all of it felt unique and challenging. I loved moments like breaking into vaults filled with treasures in Vivec. Or finding amazing loot just placed in hiding spots for you to find, that could really help you in game, I recall the 'Sword of White Woe' being hidden in a guard tower ontop of a tall wardrobe. I could either use my stealth to get it, lure the guard, or assassinate the guard... I assassinated. :D
-Differnet quality lockpicks, and probes(probes are used to disarm traps on doors/chests). Also different quality alchemy tools, and not  just a mortar and pestle, but also alembic, retort, and callcinator! I really felt like an alchemist with all those tools in Master Quality.
-The enchantments on enchanted items can be cast as normal spells! A ring can have healing on it and may have 5 uses an ingame day, so you can keep that ring handy to heal you through out your exploring! (Fargoth heuheu)
-Your player gold as an actual item!!! So you can store it! I really liked that. :)
-Jiub.


Negatives:
-Walking is really slow... So when you have to make that inevitable long trip where there are no transportation or teleportation methods, it will take ages.
-Cliff Racers.
-Some people may hate the lack of guidance in the game; I loved the extra challenge though and I found it forced me to get fully immersed in the game. I really had to listen to/read and remember what people said.
-It's hard to sell your really expensive items as there are not many vendors with large sums of gold...
-You are over encumbered"....

Skyrim why u no have levitation :("

reviewText:
The Elder Scrolls III Morrowind is one of the best purchases and games I have ever played in my life. I had first played Morrowind back in Middle School on the old Xbox system and fell in love with the world, the mystery, and the open endedness of the game world. After wanting the game really bad, I decided to purchase it on Steam and it was a wise decision. Morrowind gives the player the ability to truly do whatever they please, create the character of their dreams, and explore an enormous world with amazing characters, creatures, and cities to explore. The Elder Scrolls III Morrowind is certainly one of the best Elder Scrolls games I have played out of the entire series and I wish more of the game would have the same feel as Morrowind. I would certainly recommend Morrowind if you love a good RPG, but also if you love open ended exploreation and the ability to go anywhere and do anything you please. Out of 5 stars, I would give Morrowind a 5.

Also included in this purchase is the official expansion packs for Morrowind as well. The first expansion pack The Elder Scrolls III: Tribunal takes the player to a new location called Mournhold the capital of Morrowind Proper. The expansion is exciting but after a few hours of exploring it does get boring as it is possible to discover everything you can in this expansion. The city does add more quests to the game which is exciting but the quests are certaintly not easy and may take a while, but that is what makes the expansion great. Of course if you purchase Morrowind on Steam you will automantically get this expansion, but out of 5 stars, I would give Tribunal a 3.

The second expansion pack is The Elder Scrolls III: Bloodmoon, which adds a large island territory called Solstheim which the player can travel to and complete new quests to stop the Bloodmoon prophecy from taking place. The island adds even more beautiful scenery, creatures, and towns and cities to be discovered. It is certainly an entertaining expansion as the player is exposed to new landscapes different from those of Vvardenfell and it adds yet another good 15 hours to the already massive game. Of course if you purchase Morrowind on Steam you will automatically get this expansion, but out of 5 stars, I would give Bloodmoon a 5.

reviewText:
I could go into a lot of detail, but I'll keep this brief. This easily one of the best games ever made. At the very least, it's one of the best RPGs ever made.  (THE best in my humble opinion.) It's depth and complexity is completely unlike any game made today. There is infintely more to every single aspect of the game than just what meets they eye. The quests, the main story, the characters, the magic, the stat system.
-There is absolutely no hand holding
-This game will never forgive you for being inexperienced
-You can't just go around chopping everything in your path to bits like you can in Skyrim. There are creatures that will absolutely decimate you without mercy.
-You'll get lost trying to find places (A lot)
-You'll get confused and stuck on quests
-You will struggle to create a character with decent stats
-You will miss important items or details
-Spend hours upon hours trudging through the wilderness at a snail's pace
-I'm not joking. Speed is an ACTUAL SKILL you have to level up.
-You will fail to hit a mudcrab standing right in front of you with your weapon
-You will be forever finding new gameplay mechanics, locations, or items you never knew existed.
-You will love the music
-You will develop and ungodly hatred for cliffracers
-YOU CAN KILL MAIN QUESTLINE CHARACTERS. Pay attention. If you kill certain characters you might not ever be able to complete some quests or guilds.

The game is not without it's shortcomings, but (some of) it's flaws are part of the fun. Yes, the graphics are bad but it's 15 years old for crying out loud. That's what mods are for. The combat system can be frustrating at first when your skills are low. There is no magicka generation. Glicthes, bugs and exploits are not uncommon.

THE BOTTOM LINE- This game is an absolute masterpiece. Buy it right now. Cherish it, bask in it's glory. You won't regret it.

reviewText:
I'm splitting my review into a few major talking points - feel free to skip to  the end for a tl;dr. If you haven't played Morrowind, you should buy this game and at least attempt to play 3-5 hours before deciding you don't like it.
For a new player that hasn't been recently/ever exposed to, or doesn't enjoy, old games - Morrowind will require effort to play for the first few hours. I purchased Morrowind GOTY Edition in 2003; I've easily logged 400+ hours of gameplay over the last 13 years, and this is by far, my favorite game of all time.  Depsite this fact, it did take some time after just recently buying this game on Steam to adjust to the gameplay.

Talking point breakdown:

1. Morrowind was released in 2002. You can bash the quality of the graphics, the seemingly clunky gameplay, and the numerous gameplay bugs - but you need to realize, this was two-thousand and ****ing two we're talking about. In 2002, an above-average computer would have less than 512MB of RAM, a 50GB HDD (keeping in mind SATA didn't exist yet), and a single-core processor that may rarely exceed 2GHz. Today, you can buy a mobile phone with equivalent or greater processing power, storage, and memory for 1/10th of the price. That being said, you can't expect this game to be the lovechild of Skyrim and Crysis 3. This game was incredibly advanced for its time, and managed to be years ahead of competing RPGs for several years following its release.

2. Morrowind was designed and developed, in its entirety, by a team of less than forty engineers, artists, musicians, and writers. Skyrim, the most recent installment of the TES series, required ninety people to make a game that is effectively equivalent in size to both of its two predecessors (Oblivion and Morrowind).

3. Morrowind features depth in character development, lore, dialog, and faction stories that is unparalleled, even by modern standards. During this game, we're put into a world of religious fanatacism, xenophobia, feudalism, political struggle, corruption, and betrayal. Though this game may not feature the faction mechanics of Fallout 4, players who invest their interest will be put in the position to question their role in shaping Vvardenfell's future.

4. Morrowind uses cultural, geographic, political, and architectural variety to create an incredibly unique world for the player to explore. In my opinion, recent TES installments (futhermore, modern games in general) seem to fall short when it comes to giving players an environment with any form of variety. Both Skyrim and Oblivion (the latter of which I enjoyed thoroughly), feature textbook fantasy land and cityscapes with left-versus-right conflicts/themes (Oblivion vs. Empire, Tamriel vs. Dragons). In comparison, Morrowind features six local political factions, three skill-based factions, three religious factions, and four large-scale government-like organizations. The combination of these political, geographical, and religious influences effectively shape the architecture, social behavior, and demographics of each area.

5. Morrowind's skill, leveling, and difficulty systems are significantly more complex and intimidating than Oblivion's or Skyrim's. In Skyrim/Oblivion, you can walk into an arbitrary dungeon on your first day and fight levelled enemies with armor in your current tier. In Morrowind, you can stumble into a dungeon only to find that the enemies are anywhere from 1-30 levels above you, with weapon/armor tiers anywhere from iron to daedric. Players need to understand that this is how the game was intended to be, as the difference between entry-level and end-game areas/content should be fairly clear. As for the division of melee skills into weapon classifications, that's just how it was done - you'll learn to adapt into a clear playstyle once you actually play the game, instead of writing a scathing review after you realize this isn't an old, shot-for-shot remake of Skyrim.

6. In Morrowind, the development team wasn't afraid to push the boundries on creativity of flora/fauna. The game features everything from sky-jellyfish to dinosaurs, and fire-blasting beetles to hog-riding snowpeople. This is something that isn't really seen, at least to the same extent, in Oblivion/Skyrim - whose worlds feature fairly mundane creatures in comparison.

7. Morrowind's journal/navigation/quest system was designed to have the player commit to their role in the game. As it is in real life, you don't immediately know where a foreign location is because someone tells you about it - you need to explore, ask around, and eventually locate it yourself. Furthermore, if you want to understand what is actually going in, you need to pay attention to the dialog. Unlike Skyrim, the quality/depth of the story is greater than that of middle schooler's creative writing assignment - so it's worth paying attention to what's going on.

9.  **** This is my most important point **** - if you haven't completed, or even played Morrowind previously, DO NOT USE ONLINE GUIDES OR VIEW QUEST WALKTHROUGHS WHILE YOU PLAY. When I first owned this game, I did not have Internet regularly available to me. This game features puzzles, riddles, clues, and directions that are effectively spoiled if you cheat and use guides.

9. Finally, I do have to address some of the points that many of the negative reviews on this game dwell over.
i) The combat system is not seamless; you don't always hit with arrows and swords, and (especially at the start) casting spells successfully is quite annoying. Whether or not these features are intentional is debated; however, it does not by any means make the game unplayable.

ii) Players who started with Skyrim/Oblivion may not like the way enchanting and alchemy are carried out.

iii) The graphics to this game, obviously, aren't on par with Skyrim or Oblivion. Just remember that this game is probably older (or at least more mature) than you, if you started on Skyrim/Oblivion.

iv) Morrowind still has many bugs, some of which can be gamebreaking.  Do not be afraid to investigate how to use the console to fix issues. Useful commands include PlaceAtPC, RA, and PCJoinFaction - at least for resolving issues with disappearing characters, quest glitches, etc. Bethesda games have, and continue to feature many bugs at/after release, and Morrowind is no exception.

v) Morrowind is, by no means, optimized for the modern computer. This game was designed when people considered Windows XP to be advanced technology.

vi) Since the class/level system is more complicated than Skyrim/Oblivion, first-time players may have difficulty effectively creating/choosing a class. For a first-time character to explore all content, I recommend a custom class with 2-3 melee weapon skills (long blade, blunt weapon, and short blade offer the most amount of weapons), 2-3 magic skills (destruction, restoration, alteration are most entertaining, in my opinion), 2 armor skills (light and heavy are most useful long-term), marksman (because of throwing stars, darts, crossbows, bows), and athletics/acrobatics/whatever else you like.

**** tl;dr ****
Morrowind is a great game; personally my favorite. If you've never tried it before, I thoroughly recommend you put in the effort and give it a try, Though Morrowind is old and very different mechanically than Oblivion/Skyrim, it's quite possibly the best installment in the TES series because of the uniqueness of the environment, story, and lore.

reviewText:
Morrowind was my introduction to the Elder Scroll's series. I had heard many great things about it, mostly about how it emulated Gothic and the Might & Magic series which made it seem very interesting to me. And while I don't hold it in the same high esteem as many other fans it is still a game I did enjoy despite it's many flaws.

Morrowind is an exploration driven RPG. What that means is essentially that the story, combat and skills take a backseat to a huge open world that you can explore at will with little or no boundaries imposed. Now what separates a good exploration RPG from a bad one is both the uniqueness of the locations you can explore and especially the challenge of those locations. One of the worst mistakes an exploration RPG can make is to use leveled enemies or any similar system. If the chance of you entering a new cave only to be running out 30 seconds later with a big scary monster in close pursuit is a non factor then it will quickly become boring and predictable. Likewise if every location is too similar to the last one you will lose that driven to find new caves and castles to loot.

While the challenge you get from skipping too far ahead is not quite as good as you can find in other games and the locations do have a number of repeats Morrowind still does a good enough job that you will want to keep searching for new locations and secrets. A number of very cool travel abilities, in particular the one that allows you to jump halfway across the island in a single bound, makes for some very good exploration at times.

In terms of combat however the game is very simple and not very entertaining, killing enemies feels more like a chore than anything else and although the spell making system and enchantment system is somewhat interesting it doesn't help enough that you won't find yourself dreading running into yet another enemy. The equipment and loot system is fairly detailed but not very well thought out, mostly notably the clothing/armor system is needlessly complicated without that complexity actually adding anything to the game.

The storyline and dialog is not particularly impressive, not as much because of a lack of quality but because there isn't really enough of it to be judged and what little there is tends to be very generic and not very detailed. The quests should be mentioned as some of the most mind numbing that an RPG can dish up with, the majority being simple fed-ex jobs that challenges only your ability to stay awake.

In the end, despite every negative thing I've brought up about this game and every negative thing I've forgot to bring up, I still enjoyed it. I enjoyed it simply because the core gameplay mechanic, the exploration, worked. And that is the most important thing for a game to accomplish. It might not be a hall of fame game in my book, but it was still a good play and a game that played to it's strengths.

reviewText:
Note: You can buy Morrowind without DRM on GoG, so I would probably recommend buying it there.

Morrowind is a famously good game, but it has many factors that must be considered before touching it, these are the six that come to my mind:
1. The combat system is terrible. The later games may be simplified, but the combat systems actually work in those games. This is the only real flaw I have with the game. You can defend it all you want, but the combat is terrible, and drags the entire game down, and is one of the few areas the sequels actually did better in.
2. Difficulty. I like difficulty, but those who like Oblivion and Morrowind spoon-feeding you will hate this game. I think it makes this a real RPG, but some may disagree. However, the difficulty can be annoying, as some enemies can kill you in a single swing, or in twenty swings. It is really inconsistant.
3. Navigation: As said above, the game does not hold your hand at all. There is no compass, quest markers, or other forms of game help, just your ability to ask questions and follow directions that your character puts in their journal. This once again enriches the RPG elements, but may put off those coming from its sequels.
4. Oblivion and Skyrim are much easier to play. They are Action-RPG games; this has more RPG elements than its successors. This makes the game seem better for some, but can be a pulling factor to some.
5. As it’s older, it naturally won't look as nice. The game has aged somewhat fine, but other games have aged more gracefully. The Morrowind Graphics Overhaul mod makes it look great though, leaving you with the now outdated gameplay mechanics.
6. There is a lot of text to read. If you can't read or follow text directions, ♥♥♥♥ off.

Outside of this, the game has far more focus on the lore of the Elder Scrolls universe as well. The land is far more alien than Cyrodiil or Skyrim, and the variety of environments is far wider than what is found in subsequent instalments. The world is therefore far more interesting and engaging than later instalments, and this is the final Elder Scrolls game to not include fast travel (outside of transport services), so like it or not, you will walk, sprint and jump your way across the world.

If you are ready for the last Elder Scrolls game to focus more on RPG elements than action elements, then I'd recommend. However, if the many broken elements of this game put you off, then don't bother. Morrowind is the last Elder Scrolls game really aimed at a niche market.

reviewText:
TL;DR Review:
Morrowind is a unique entry in the Elder Scrolls series that is just as fun, engaging and addictive as its big brothers Oblivion and Skyrim, but you will have to work a bit harder to get to the rich nougaty center.

Long Review:
Morrowind was the first Elder Scrolls game to be released for the Windows platform, and it's clear that Bethesda rewrote the engine from the ground up.  Gone were the problematic, randomly-generated dungeons of Daggerfall.  Now all content would be hand-created, using specialized tools to still allow the massive amounts of content that hallmark an Elder Scrolls game.

The setting deserves a special mention - it's as far away from your standard generic fantasy setting as possible.  Green gives way to volcanic grey, red and purple.  You fight giant insects, dinosaur-like creatures and steampunk constructs.  Trees give way to cities built under huge mushrooms and massive stone formations.  You travel between cities tucked inside the hollowed-out shell of a giant bug.  It's almost like adventuring in an alien world instead of a fantasy one.

There is a lot to do.  Over ninety dungeons to raid, four cities and thirteen towns to explore, three noble houses and four guilds to join - each of which has their own questline.  And that's not even touching the main plot, which is arguably the best one ever written for an Elder Scrolls game.

Downsides?  Of course.  There's no fast travel, so you'll initially be doing a lot of walking around.  But between the silt striders (the giant bugs mentioned above), teleportation between mage's guilds, scrolls of intervention and the Mark and Recall spells, you'll eventually be jumping around Morrowind with ease, and it feels more realistic.

The leveling system isn't quite as broken as the one in Oblivion but it's not as good as Skyrim.  And the progression isn't balanced well - you'll spend a long time feeling like a shmuck and then suddenly you'll be a godling.

Also, because this version includes both expansion packs, early on in the game you'll be attacked by a fairly difficult enemy.  This fight can be hard for new players, but if you persevere your reward will be an excellent set of light armor that will make the rest of the early game much easier.

I'm not big on mods for Morrowind, but I'd recommend the Morrowind Code Patch, especially if you play a stealthy character because it enables sneak-toggle (by default you have to hold down the sneak button for as long as you're sneaking).  It also does other silly, inconsequential things like fix a ton of crashes and savegame corruptions.  You can learn more about it and get it here:

http://www.uesp.net/wiki/Tes3Mod:Morrowind_Code_Patch

If you've never played an Elder Scrolls game, I would strongly suggest you start here.  If you played Oblivion or Skyrim and want more, Morrowind will pay off for you in spades.  I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Morrowind's greatest triumph is that it crafts a distinctly unique fantasy world, from its various cultures and politics to its dwellings, landscapes, and species.  There is a great deal to discover and an epic story to be experienced - one that still stands as one of the best, even all these years later.

However, the game is not without its flaws.  In particular, combat and its related skills are a bit unrefined.  For example, you won't be able to hit anything with melee attacks until you raise your melee skill, which is only raised by successfully hitting things.  Luckily, this game was very popular and you can find many mods to get around the aspects of the game that aren't up to modern snuff.

If you have the time and see what fantasy can be like when it isn't just piggy-backing off of Tolkien, play this game!

reviewText:
Morrowind in my opinion is the best installment in the Elder Scrolls series so far. The amount of content and freedom the game offers you is insane. It's the type of game that doesn't tend to hold your hand, but give it a chance and the game will open itself up to you and you'll soon find yourself sucked in to it's world.

The graphics and battle system may be a little too outdated for some, but because of the games awesome modding community, there's a variety of mods you can choose from to improve your experience (i recommend Morrowind Overhaul).

The best thing about this game is that YOU choose how you want to play. Boasting a huge open world, hundreds of quests, a variety of races and classes to choose from, you'll never run out of things to do.

I invite you to give this game a try, for the amount of content you get in game, it's definitely worth the asking price.

reviewText:
Back on xbox it took me a few years to beat the game even with cheats.
Buying on PC was probably the most nostaglic thing I did. I started out like I normally did with my old plays and then I came across the console.
My trolly side just couldn't help it'self. I created a new play, maxed out my character so all my stats were full.

Insulted that he would even suggest that I was lacking the required materials to defeat him I had used my own godly powers to prove him wrong. With Sunder, Wraithguard and Keening suddenly in my posession the Dagoth Ur was curtain that he was ready to take me on. With two swift hits he decided that it be best to move along into the next room. Turns out I could still take part in all the main story quests that lead up to the magnificent display of my powers. I was quite pleased by this.
10/10 would use console commands again.

reviewText:
I've been in love with Morrowind since I first played my cousin's copy on the original Xbox shortly after the game first launched. I had to have it, I was blown away. I got the PC version as quickly as I could and discovered it had an active and ambitious modding community that at the time I had never even thought was possible and I was hooked even more.

Fast forward something like 13 years later and I still love this game. It brings me back to my childhood and the still-active mod community has helped extend its life and helps it keep competing with its younger siblings: Oblivion and Skyrim. While those two games are better in other areas, they never succeeded in recapturing the charm, or sense of boundless adventure and exploration that Morrowind excelled at. It's reflected in the music of each game, Morrowind's theme just fills you with wonder and awe, just as the game world did.

Morrowind is easily one of the best games ever made and it'll keep on living for some time yet. I cannot recommend it enough, though I stress that it not be played in its vanillia, or unaltered, state. At the very least you should install Morrowind Overhaul Sound & Graphics along with it. It has all the essential patches and mods and can set your game up good to go right there. And if certain things like standards set in Oblivion and Skyrim that aren't in Morrowind bother you (such as health/magicka regen or attacks always hitting) there are mods for that as well as ones to help you get around more easily. Just about every it's not like Oblivion/Skyrim" issue has mod out there to address it. This game's strength is how far its mods can go. Something that Oblivion and Skyrim were never as good at."

reviewText: This was my first Elder Scrolls Game and is one of my favorite games of all time. I first played it on the Xbox. When I first saw my brother playing it I thought it was stupid as I seen my brother wandering the world and I always refused to try it. But one day he made me try the game and then I was addicted. When I first played the game I didn’t do any quest I just got a house the good old way by killing its owner in Ald-Ruhn, Gnisis and Khuul. Later on in 2008 I got the game for the PC and made mods that I dreamed of playing. I don’t mod the game anymore but I still play the game and it never gets old. I also play the game for quests now unlike I did when I first played and that the best part of the Elder Scrolls series. Your free to wander, kill, steal, help others, betray, travel by foot, swim, travel by boat or silt strider which is their stagecoaches, it was endless. And If you got bored I always started a new save and it was memories all over again. The two expansion packs Tribunal and Bloodmoon are the best expansions packs I've ever played in any Elder Scrolls game, especially Bloodmoon. It adds a green forest and snowy environment which isn't available in the rest of the game. And the Tribunal expansion only added a city but a big city to the game with a 20 hour main storyline which I thought was impressive and very enjoyable. And the free little add-on DLCs that were made by Bethesda are pretty cool too especially the Seige At Firemoth plug-in. I recommend this game to anyone who hasn’t played an Elder Scrolls game and if you have played an Elder Scrolls game you may want to get mods and high-res textures that make it more like the newer Elder Scrolls game so it doesn’t seem old to you such as the games combat, menus, or graphic. Its an older game and for some gamers its maybe too old for them and not enjoyable. If you unsure watch some gameplay to decide for yourself.

reviewText:
I have played this game since it came out in 2002, and it continues to be my personal favorite of The Elder Scrolls series. The story is compelling, and actually draws you into the world unlike in Skyrim, and Oblivion. Don't get me wrong that Skyrim and Oblivion don't draw you in. They do, just not on the same scale.
Advancing in a Faction requires you to be proficent in their favored skills, not just doing the quests.
There are NO limits to what you can do if you really think about it.
Have you ever wanted to make a ring or amulet that lets you Levitate forever? This game engine lets you do that, you just have to make it yourself.
Do you want to use the soul of a God to power a pair of slippers? Go for it.
Have I replayed this game over and over? Of course.
Do I recommend that you play this through before playing Skywind? Absolutely.

reviewText:
The best Elder Scrolls title, hands down.

At the start of the game, you are thrown into an alien world, one that you would never expect to see youself in. Everything is different, to the odd fungus flora, to the floating jellyfish that are the Netch. You start as a lowly Outlander, and are constantly told that you, are a worthless outlander. And you don't belong. But as you progress, that will change. You will become an Outlander who barely can swing a sword, to the Nerevarine, legendary Dunmer Saint who can kill gods, and capture their souls.

The satisfaction of this makes the game very rewarding and fun to play. Not to mention the amazing spell-creation system, that allows you to create any spell imaginable.

Now other than that, let's talk Story. Morrowind tells one of the greatest stories you will ever partake in. The 6th House has risen, and a blight pollutes Vvardenfell. Will you be the one to save Vvardenfell from this blight, and destroy the evil Dagoth Ur, who dwells in Red Mountain? Or who knows, you might just become arch-mage of Great House Telvanni. All of this is up to you.

I definitely recommend Morrowind to anyone who enjoys a good story, a great RPG/openworld game, and a piece of art. But don't let graphics put you off! Morrowind is an amazing, must-play game! Alas, some people may be scaared of these bad" graphics. That's why there's Morrowind Graphics and Sound Overhaul! It makes the game look like any modern game

reviewText:
I'm going to open with pointing out my bias, because I played and loved this game endlessly on XBox back when it came out.

Objectively, the graphics are very dated, and the gameplay does feel a little clunky. However if you're any fan of more classic RPG's, you need to give this game a look. Before Oblivion's more medieval landscape (Shivering Isles exheunt) and before Skyrim's Canada, Morrowind built a beautiful fantasy landscape, filled with spectacular creatures, varied characters, dwarven mechanations, and original quests.Technically speaking, the sound and graphics aren't much to speak of (though the music is adventurous, and really ups the experience). There is not much voice acting to speak of in most of this game, instead Bethesda opted for text boxes to save space. However, this opens the door for so much lore, and flavor text (which is important, damnit!) that this feels like the best crafted version of the Elder Scrolls universe.

The game isn't levelled like it's predecessors, the world stays as it is, and you start out pretty weak. But it pushes you to be strong, and if you put the time in, you can overcome every challenge. There isn't a lot of emphasis on balance, because like a classic RPG, this game doesn't hold your hand. There isn't a compass to help you find quest points, instead you have a journal which subjectively directs you to your quest goal. For example, The cave is north of Seyda Neen
date: a bit past the bridge on the river." It feels like a real adventure
recommended: going through it.\n\nIf I were to price it: 30-Full price due to the age. But the game now can be found for incredibly cheap
hoursPlayed: I recommend it to anyone who enjoys a hard RPG experience."

reviewText: I have well over 500 hours in Skyrim (counting all platforms), 350 hours in Oblivion and probably around 350 hours in Morrowind in total...so far, and it is my opinion that Morrowind gives the best RPG and TES experience of this threesome (I am leaving out Arena and Daggerfall as I haven't really gotten around to playing them properly yet). The main story of Morrowind (which is the only real questline in the game without the expansions) is simply many levels above what is presented to us in Oblivion and Skyrim as I see it. Even though the graphics are now very outdated, I still feel the game world in Morrowind feels more real" than in the two latest games - the reason for this is probably that Morrowind is much more lore-rich and that no matter where you go and what you do you still feel connected with the main plot and the workings of Dunmer society (which you will be intimately familiar with in this game).\n\nMorrowind's greatest asset is probably the sense of wonder and strangeness the game world instills in the player and its very rewarding exploration. Some have called Morrowind "the last real TES game"
date: and while I'm not going to make that claim it is clear that the dumbing down of the series and the extreme hand-holding of the player in say Skyrim has not exactly made the series take a direction that I'm very happy with. In Morrowind you often have to read to discover what to do and where to go at times and at other times you will have to think - there are no quest markers in this game to ruin this part of the game.\n\nMany people complain about the combat in Morrowind
recommended: and reasonably so if the game is to be compared to modern action titles - this was never the point however: this game is supposed to be an RPG with many mechanics taken from table-top RPG gaming. Seen in this light the combat system is altogether decent and in my opinion can be quite fun. In vanilla Morrowind for instance you can not manually block with your shield
hoursPlayed: something that probably sounds ridiculous to modern players - it makes perfect sense though seen from the perspective of old-school RPG-gaming where it is your character's stats and abilities that govern the outcome of an action and not the players own skills of reaction and button-timing and what not.\n\nAll in all I strongly recommend this game and I urge all fans of TES to try it out no matter their feelings about the lack of an action-oriented combat system
voteText: because in my opinion this game is simply a better RPG experience than we get in Oblivion or Skyrim. A far better one. Oblivion and Skyrim are games I will probably never play again (been there done that...)

reviewText: I bought this game back in the early retail days, but due to a fire I lost that copy. I recently found Morrowind, Oblivion and Skyrim on sale with all downloadable content/expansions for cheap here on Steam, so I bought them. I loved the sheer variety of the paths you could travel and guilds/factions you could join. You could enchant your clothing/armor and weapons with magical effects, pick locks, cast awesome destructive abilities, heal, affect your enviroment, etc. I liked the fact you had 10 major/minor skills that leveled you up, but I hated the level 50ish limit on your levels. In order to maximize your stat bonuses you needed to micromanage your skill growth to an absurd level in order to achieve the 100 stats.  Also, after you do the available faction quests (again, you can't join but ONE of the three Great Houses, which does make some sense, but you can join opposing factions, such as the thieves guild, and the imperial legion, or the morag tong, which is almost the same boat.) and the Great House of your choice and the expansions, you can roam the lands to find random quests from people along the roadways.\n\nOverall grade: 9.8/10

reviewText:
Now that i beat it for the second time i can comfortably review this game. imma keep it short and sweet.

Pros!
+Vast attribute system [lots of different ways to level up and customize your character if you wanna make your class.]
+Long and engaging story with a lore deeper than the rest of the Elder Scrolls games.
+Enchanting weapons and armor and accessories has never felt better, so many different ways to customize as long as you have means to
+Vast open world with many secrets to discover. a very diverse landscape indeed which is probably why i didnt favor skyrim that much seeing as how it was smaller and less diverse with a few secrets.
+a soundtrack unlike any other, absolutely beautiful.
+Combat is quite unique. although it may not be the best, spell creation and badass enchanted weapons do make up.
Cons.
-Not very good looking in terms of asthetics, didnt age too well. [strongly reccomend getting the Overhaul 3.0]
-Combat is not the best. [refer to the last Pro]
-Requires alot of reading to get through it. [not nessarily a bad thing, just pointing out how most people wont like it as opposed to skyrims quest markers. git gud]

Overall : 9/10 Definately one of the most unforgettable Rpg Experiences out there to date. till this day i have not played an RPG that could engage me like Morrowind did. I reccomend giving this game a try if you a hardcore fan of the series.
