reviewText: Morrowind is and always will be a true masterpeice that is the crown jewel of classic RPGS. Yes, I said it, the CROWN JEWEL, sorry Occarina of Time!\n\nMorrowind is not for the faint-hearted kid fans of Skyrim who play it like it's a hack and slash. It is not for picky, complaining adults who point every little fault out and refuse to enjoy games for what they are. Morrowind is for hardcore RPG players, the people who can just get lost in the world for days at a time wanting to find every city and do every quest. It's for those of us who can sit down, start up the game, and find our way through with no in-game quest markers at all, instead using strategy, creativity, and logic. And above all, Morrowind is for true Elder Scrolls fans, with history books scattered around the world and a story that ingeniously weaves it's way deep into the past and present of the Elder Scrolls timeline. Overall, if you are a hack and slash fan of Skyrim and not the whole franchise, who will pick apart a game just to find something to complain about, this game is not for you, so don't buy it. Period. If you are an RPG gamer and a true fan of the Elder Scrolls, get Morrowind NOW. Seriously, get it now, you are missing out on a great game!

reviewText: Morrowind is quite possibly my favorite game of all time. Don't let the number of hours played on my profile fool you; when I had this for the Xbox, my main save alone was probably at least 200 hours. Morrowind was my introduction to the Elder Scrolls series, and as such it holds a special place in my heart. Anyone who is a fan of RPG's and hasn't played this game yet should do so immediately. The gameplay is solid, the plot is rich and engrossing, and the world is enormous and almost alien in the way that it looks nothing like what you would expect a fantasy world to look like. Really, that itself is the beauty of the Elder Scrolls games. Bethesda has created a world which draws on the typical fantasy ideas, and then turns them on their heads to create an atmosphere which is completely unique. Where else would you find cannibalistic wood elves, dwarves who aren't really dwarves, or bipedal lizards who worship a race of magical, sentient trees? Only in The Elder Scrolls.\n\nA word of warning, though: for anyone who is used to the gameplay in Oblivion/Skyrim, you may be in for a rude awakening. While the newer Elder Scrolls games have become more streamlined" and "action-y
date: Morrowind is an RPG in the truest sense of the word. The most noticeable difference is in the way combat works. In Oblivion/Skyrim, you stand in front of someone, swing your sword, and hit them. In Morrowind, you could be right in front of an enemy and completely miss. This is because Morrowind uses the old-school dice-rolling mechaninc to determine if your attacks are successful or not. Even your spells can fail to cast if you're not proficient enough in that particular school of magic. No, it's not lag. No, the hitboxes are not broken. That's just the way a real RPG works. Things like this can be frustrating to newer players who aren't used to it, which is completely understandable. But for those who persevere and get past this learning curve, you will be treated to one of the most rewarding and memorable gaming experiences ever. You won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
In Morrowind, my character:
-has killed a living god
-destroyed an Aedric artifact
-is the head of House Hlaalu
-is amused by the Telvanni tradition of violently murdering political opposition
-has talks and meditates with Vivec
-shoots Daedra in the face with a crossbow
-has achieved CHIM

10/10 will play again

Seriously though, the atmosphere in Morrowind is amazingly well-crafted. I cannot yet speak for any of the earlier games (as I haven't played them), but Morrowind really is the best TES game I've played. I started with Skyrim and worked my way back. It isn't just nostalgia bias talking when people say Morrowind is amazing; it truly is a culmination of very hard work and insane attention to detail. It rewards you and doesn't insult your intelligence by putting the solutions to puzzles on the wall *cough* Skyrim *cough*. Everything you do, from joining the Temple to fulfilling the prophecy of the Nerevarine, has a noticeable impact on the world. People react to your actions; Bethesda nails this quite well. Whether you're going out to kill Mudcrabs that dragged off a Guar from some random lady's farm in the wilderness or playing politics to manipulate the ebony trade in your house's favor, every moment of Morrowind is rewarding. But that's also the beauty of it: It doesn't force you into anything. Nothing just screams out at you. You have to put the work in to enjoy the game. And once you do, the world and its story slowly unfolds before your eyes. There are so many moments in Morrowind that grabbed me and opened my eyes on a new range of perspectives that there's absolutely no way I could ever hope to count them. Don't let anyone lie to you; this game is incredibly frustrating and difficult at times, but the reward for working through it is one of the best gamplay experiences of all time. My only hope is that Bethesda will make a game as well-crafted, clever, and gripping as Morrowind again some day.

reviewText:
This game is the most nostalgic, atmospheric, and immersive Elder Scrolls games out there by far. I understand many people love Oblivion, or Skyrim. For many that's because its the series they came into the Elder Scrolls on, and I can understand that. For me though, I've seen the game-play simplified and degraded from Morrowind, to Oblivion, and to Skyrim. While Skyrim went back to its Morrowind Roots a little more, it was still extremely simplified. Health, Mana, Energy for your stats.. that's it?...

Morrowind is a testament to itself, as even in 2016 its a widely loved, played, and even modded game to this day. It has all the old school gameplay which gamers should love in an RPG. Extensive and in depth stats, deep and meaningful gameplay, immersive quests, situations, and world. Thousands upon thousands of hidden little side stories, quests, and situations in the world you could easily over look if you weren't paying attention. For every minute you immersive yourself in this game, you'll get that back ten fold in enjoyment. This game truly is a true open world in terms of being able to play how you want, when you want, where you want, and being able to make your character be who you want them to be with virtually no limitations.

-------------------------------------------------------

The Character and your Stats

Your character in Morrowind has very deep and meaningful stats. Unlike Oblivoin and Skyrim, each weapon type, Armor Type, etc. (and there's more than Oblivion or Skyrim), has its own stat tied to it.

Character Skills: Heavy Armor, Medium Armor, Spear, Acrobatics, Armorer, Axe, Blunt Weapon, Long Blades, Block, Light Armor, Marksman, Sneak Athletics, Hand to Hand, Short Blade, Unarmored, Illusion, Mercantile, Speechcraft, Alchemy, Conjuration, Enchant, SEcurity, Alteration, Destruction, Mysticism, Restoration

Character Stats: Agility, Endurance, Intelligence, Luck, Personality, Speed, Strength, Willpower, Health, Magicka, Fatigue, Encumberance, etc.

These skills and stats allow you to truly make a character be exactly who you want them to be however. Want to make a real berserker that actually acts like one? Major Skill into Axes, Unarmored, Light Armor, Speed, with Minors being Block, Armorer, etc. Run around in almost no armor wielding axes.

Make a mage that feels like a real mage, with Unarmored, and the vast variety of magic skills and spells. The coolest thing about MOrrowind is you can make spells that never existed easily within the game. I'll go into that more.

Exploration, Quests, and the World - It's open ended

As this section says, it really is open ended. There are nearly 500 quests in Morrowind with its expansions. (I believe the exact number is 490ish give or take a few), and most of these are open ended quests.

reviewText: I love this game and have played it many times over the years. There is a rich and complex lore. There are lots of quirky characters and some downright silly side quests. There is a sense of epic scale, both in geography and story. The two expansion packs offered solid additional adventures for the protagonist. You can be just about anyone and do just about anything. Graphics are dated but easily spruced up with mods--and there is of course a robust modding community still out there. Dealing with even simple encounters in the early few levels can be frustratingly difficult (especially given the percent chance to hit based on skill level, so even point-blank perfectly aimed attacks often miss), and if you have adequately leveled your character then the very end-game content can really reduce the game to a pattern of repeated clicking to kill things, barring a few overpowered encounters (rather disappointing, as it really makes obvious that so much of the way the player interacts with the game is through violence); besides these points, though, I would describe the game as nearly flawless (if it wasn't infamously and maybe even fondly known for a bevy of bugs). I would highly recommend, whether you've played any Elder Scrolls games or not. Never too late to give this great title a try.

reviewText: Morrowind is and always will be a true masterpeice that is the crown jewel of classic RPGS. Yes, I said it, the CROWN JEWEL, sorry Occarina of Time!\n\nMorrowind is not for the faint-hearted kid fans of Skyrim who play it like it's a hack and slash. It is not for picky, complaining adults who point every little fault out and refuse to enjoy games for what they are. Morrowind is for hardcore RPG players, the people who can just get lost in the world for days at a time wanting to find every city and do every quest. It's for those of us who can sit down, start up the game, and find our way through with no in-game quest markers at all, instead using strategy, creativity, and logic. And above all, Morrowind is for true Elder Scrolls fans, with history books scattered around the world and a story that ingeniously weaves it's way deep into the past and present of the Elder Scrolls timeline. If you are an RPG gamer and a true fan of the Elder Scrolls, get Morrowind NOW. Seriously, get it now, you are missing out on a great game!

reviewText:
The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind is not Skyrim minus two. It is a very different game. I am not going to spend the entirety of this review telling you it's better than Skyrim and that you have to agree with me. You're a modern TES fan and want to play Morrowind? Hmm. I'm not going to tell you to go back to Skyrim, as I haven't played it personally and my entire view of the game is based on what I hear from friends and YouTube. Here's the problem with playing Morrowind: It takes AGES to actually get into the game and start enjoying it. Character creation takes ages and needs to be thought out. Also, the combat system. Most people will tell you that the combat system is dated and terrible. While the former may be true, the latter certainly isn't. Once you're a few levels up, combat becomes more mindless. Your character will have tons of stats and skills, all of which have an effect on one or more gameplay elements. Combat is based on dice rolls. Whenever you swing your sword at an enemy, there is an initial dice roll. This dice rolls is affected by your many skills and other stats. I'm not going to ramble about starting out and what you should do, but I'll leave a link to my favourite guide at the end of this review. Once you have done some of the main quest, levelled up a load, and know how to succeed in combat you can start exploring and side questing. This, in my opinion, is the best part of Morrowind. Join the mages guild and learn how to make your own potions that you can sell for a profit. learn to enchant and make a cloak of invisibility. Make a ring that allows you to fly whenever you wear it. Boots that let you run at ridiculous speed. None of these are pre-programmed items, you can make them yourself. Maybe you'd like to join the Morag Tong, a shady underground association of assassins. You could literally just wander the lands of Vvardenfell and look for adventure. Morrowind has an excellent main quest, but it excels at letting you do whatever you like. Two expansions have been released, which increase the length of the game. Tribunal lets you visit the capital of Morrowind, Mournhold, which in itself excites me. Bloodmoon adds in the small frozen island of Solstheim, also seen in Dragonborn. These are both included in the Steam version. The game looks VERY dated, but this is easily fixed by the MGSO mod, which imporves graphics and installs tons of other patches to combat bugs. I recommend downloading it even if you're on a low end PC or a laptop and just turning off the really demanding stuff. Tamriel Rebuilt is a community made expansion that increases the size of the world map and is also highly recommended.


This is now very much a rant, so I'm going to end off here.

TL;DR
The Elder Scrolls III is extremely hard to get into, but also extremely worth it. The insane amount of freedom given to you is more than worth the first few hours spent missing attacks on mudcrabs. At the time of writing, I am exactly 100 hours into Morrowind. I have done less than half of the main quest. Don't be fooled, you don't have to spend hundreds of hours trying to beat this game. You could probably clear it in less than 50. But if you want to spend hours on end adventuring, questing and exploring, this game allows you to do that too. It has it's flaws, but those can easily be fixed by the power of mods or outright ignored.

17/10 would lose all my friends and CHIM again.


(You may have noticed that this  rant  is rather similar to SorcerorDave's 'Why You Should Still Play Morrowind in 2014' video. I'll link that too.)

The guide I used getting started: http://www.ign.com/wikis/the-elder-scrolls-iii-morrowind/Introduction
Why You Should Still Play Morrowind in 2014: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jf0jiOpD-AQ

I'm not going to tell you to go back to Skyrim, as I haven't played it personally and my entire view of the game is based on what I hear from friends and YouTube. Here's the problem with playing Morrowind: It takes AGES to actually get into the game and start enjoying it. Character creation takes ages and needs to be thought out. Also, the combat system. Most people will tell you that the combat system is dated and terrible. While the former may be true, the latter certainly isn't. Once you're a few levels up, combat becomes more mindless. Your character will have tons of stats and skills, all of which have an effect on one or more gameplay elements. Combat is based on dice rolls. Whenever you swing your sword at an enemy, there is an initial dice roll. This dice rolls is affected by your many skills and other stats. I'm not going to ramble about starting out and what you should do, but I'll leave a link to my favourite guide at the end of this review. Once you have done some of the main quest, levelled up a load, and know how to succeed in combat you can start exploring and side questing. This, in my opinion, is the best part of Morrowind. Join the mages guild and learn how to make your own potions that you can sell for a profit. learn to enchant and make a cloak of invisibility. Make a ring that allows you to fly whenever you wear it. Boots that let you run at ridiculous speed. None of these are pre-programmed items, you can make them yourself. Maybe you'd like to join the Morag Tong, a shady underground association of assassins. You could literally just wander the lands of Vvardenfell and look for adventure. Morrowind has an excellent main quest, but it excels at letting you do whatever you like. Two expansions have been released, which increase the length of the game. Tribunal lets you visit the capital of Morrowind, Mournhold, which in itself excites me. Bloodmoon adds in the small frozen island of Solstheim, also seen in Dragonborn. These are both included in the Steam version. The game looks VERY dated, but this is easily fixed by the MGSO mod, which imporves graphics and installs tons of other patches to combat bugs. I recommend downloading it even if you're on a low end PC or a laptop and just turning off the really demanding stuff. Tamriel Rebuilt is a community made expansion that increases the size of the world map and is also highly recommended.


This is now very much a rant, so I'm going to end off here.

TL;DR
The Elder Scrolls III is extremely hard to get into, but also extremely worth it. The insane amount of freedom given to you is more than worth the first few hours spent missing attacks on mudcrabs. At the time of writing, I am exactly 100 hours into Morrowind. I have done less than half of the main quest. Don't be fooled, you don't have to spend hundreds of hours trying to beat this game. You could probably clear it in less than 50. But if you want to spend hours on end adventuring, questing and exploring, this game allows you to do that too. It has it's flaws, but those can easily be fixed by the power of mods or outright ignored.

17/10 would lose all my friends and CHIM again.

reviewText: I love this game and have played it many times over the years. There is a rich and complex lore. There are lots of quirky characters and some downright silly side quests. There is a sense of epic scale, both in geography and story. The two expansion packs offered solid additional adventures for the protagonist. You can be just about anyone and do just about anything. Graphics are dated but easily spruced up with mods--and there is of course a robust modding community still out there. Dealing with even simple encounters in the early few levels can be frustratingly difficult (especially given the percent chance to hit based on skill level, so even point-blank perfectly aimed attacks often miss), and if you have adequately leveled your character then the very end-game content can really reduce the game to a pattern of repeated clicking to kill things, barring a few overpowered encounters (rather disappointing, as it really makes obvious that so much of the way the player interacts with the game is through violence); besides these points, though, I would describe the game as nearly flawless (if it wasn't infamously and maybe even fondly known for a bevy of bugs). I would highly recommend, whether you've played any Elder Scrolls games or not. Never too late to give this great title a try.

reviewText:
This game is the most nostalgic, atmospheric, and immersive Elder Scrolls games out there by far. I understand many people love Oblivion, or Skyrim. For many that's because its the series they came into the Elder Scrolls on, and I can understand that. For me though, I've seen the game-play simplified and degraded from Morrowind, to Oblivion, and to Skyrim. While Skyrim went back to its Morrowind Roots a little more, it was still extremely simplified. Health, Mana, Energy for your stats.. that's it?...

Morrowind is a testament to itself, as even in 2016 its a widely loved, played, and even modded game to this day. It has all the old school gameplay which gamers should love in an RPG. Extensive and in depth stats, deep and meaningful gameplay, immersive quests, situations, and world. Thousands upon thousands of hidden little side stories, quests, and situations in the world you could easily over look if you weren't paying attention. For every minute you immersive yourself in this game, you'll get that back ten fold in enjoyment. This game truly is a true open world in terms of being able to play how you want, when you want, where you want, and being able to make your character be who you want them to be with virtually no limitations.

-------------------------------------------------------

The Character and your Stats

Your character in Morrowind has very deep and meaningful stats. Unlike Oblivoin and Skyrim, each weapon type, Armor Type, etc. (and there's more than Oblivion or Skyrim), has its own stat tied to it.

Character Skills: Heavy Armor, Medium Armor, Spear, Acrobatics, Armorer, Axe, Blunt Weapon, Long Blades, Block, Light Armor, Marksman, Sneak Athletics, Hand to Hand, Short Blade, Unarmored, Illusion, Mercantile, Speechcraft, Alchemy, Conjuration, Enchant, SEcurity, Alteration, Destruction, Mysticism, Restoration

Character Stats: Agility, Endurance, Intelligence, Luck, Personality, Speed, Strength, Willpower, Health, Magicka, Fatigue, Encumberance, etc.

These skills and stats allow you to truly make a character be exactly who you want them to be however. Want to make a real berserker that actually acts like one? Major Skill into Axes, Unarmored, Light Armor, Speed, with Minors being Block, Armorer, etc. Run around in almost no armor wielding axes.

Make a mage that feels like a real mage, with Unarmored, and the vast variety of magic skills and spells. The coolest thing about MOrrowind is you can make spells that never existed easily within the game. I'll go into that more.

Exploration, Quests, and the World - It's open ended

reviewText: At first I was unsure if I would enjoy this game or not because of the people saying the combat system was tough or the quests were hard because there was no compass with a way-point telling you where to go since I was used to that stuff, but when I bought it I really enjoyed it. The lack of way-points gives you a reason to read every bit of text to find out where you're going to be headed and makes this game very engaging. The combat system led me to stop playing the game for about a week until I looked it up and found out that you had to be skilled in the weapon you were using and that enemies could dodge. Also I learned that you should sell items to earn money when you're starting off. Those made me be able to enjoy the game. So far at the time of this review I have 5 hours and I haven't gotten anywhere in the quests so I can expect this game to be a very long game. This game has aged very well for being 13 years old. I would rate this game 10/10.

reviewText: I love this game and have played it many times over the years. There is a rich and complex lore. There are lots of quirky characters and some downright silly side quests. There is a sense of epic scale, both in geography and story. The two expansion packs offered solid additional adventures for the protagonist. You can be just about anyone and do just about anything. Graphics are dated but easily spruced up with mods--and there is of course a robust modding community still out there. Dealing with even simple encounters in the early few levels can be frustratingly difficult (especially given the percent chance to hit based on skill level, so even point-blank perfectly aimed attacks often miss), and if you have adequately leveled your character then the very end-game content can really reduce the game to a pattern of repeated clicking to kill things, barring a few overpowered encounters (rather disappointing, as it really makes obvious that so much of the way the player interacts with the game is through violence); besides these points, though, I would describe the game as nearly flawless (if it wasn't infamously and maybe even fondly known for a bevy of bugs). I would highly recommend, whether you've played any Elder Scrolls games or not. Never too late to give this great title a try.

reviewText:
This game introduced me to sandbox style games back in 2003 or so. It completely blew my mind, I was hooked. I have no idea how many hundreds of hours I played in on the original XBOX, later on my XBOX 360, and later still on the computer before even learning what Steam was, and now you can see I have over 80 hours clocked. There will always be a place in this gamer's heart for The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind.

That being said, if I might take off my nostalgia goggles for a moment... visually... it has not aged well. There's a mod for that however, which makes it gorgeous. The only other real drawback of it is the combat system which I really don't mind. Essentially you can level up a skill to 100, and the lowest a skill starts at is 5. That is basically the percentage chance of hitting. You could be fighting a Kwama worm thing that has a disease which renders it  immobile (I assume something that decreases its already pitiful strength), and you will have a VERY hard time hitting it if your skill is only 5-15. *MISS* *MISS* *MISS* *MISS* *HIT* *MISS* *MISS*, etc. Same goes with spells, except it's your chance of casting it. The bright side is however, each race has specific things they're good at, and you can select traits Major skills which are basically what you're really good at, and Minor skills which is what you're somewhat good at.

Major skills get a boost of something like 25-30 points as I recall, while Minor ones get around 15 or so I think. There are also teachers all over Morrowind who can teach you various skills, and the lower level you are, the cheaper it is. So if you want to level up something that's only at 5-15, then do some training with a professional first. Get it up to a solid 25 or so at least before training on real enemies.

One fascinating thing about this game however is when everything loads, that's how your world is. If you know where to look, you can get some SERIOUSLY good weapons/armour, though if you end up in the wrong place at too low a level, you can get SERIOUSLY messed up by a powerful enemy. Morrowind is quite unforgiving, but if you have the patience to get to know it well, it's very much worth the effort. There are many mods available that can help clean up the visuals, and who knows, there might be some which changes it so that you ALWAYS hit but the damage done is dependant on level, like Oblivion. Though as stated, personally, I don't mind the hit/miss system. The first character you make will just be a test run, I imagine. Getting a feel for the game, trying new things. If you've played Oblivion and/or Skyrim though, and already know all the skills, then that'll give you a great head start.

Ultimately, if you don't mind lacking graphics and somewhat clunky combat systems (if you use skills you're not good at though; if you select your race/skills properly, you'll start with level 35-50 with your primary skills, then the combat is more fluid), then I can't recommend this game enough. If you DO mind lacking graphics but don't mind somewhat clunky combat systems, then I still recommend it if you know how to mod. If you mind both, do some research, see if you can mod it so that the combat system is more like Oblivion/Skyrim, and if so, have at it. This game is truly a gem. I believe it has less land than Oblivion or Skyrim, though there are DLC (which I believe is included) which adds an island and an independant city to which you can teleport, and I also recall that Morrowind has more caves/tombs than Oblivion or Skyrim so it likely has more underground terrain than the two of them.

I hope I addressed the pros and cons equally here. Oh, one thing that's always bugged me is that magicka doesn't automatically regenerate. You have to drink potions or sleep... but I never bothered looking up a mod to fix this... namely because I found it fun to simply have a drink every time I drink a potion to replenish my magicka :P As for fatigue diminishing as you run, I LOOOOVE realism, so I was saddened when I found it missing in Oblivion, allowing you to jog in full armour anywhere you like, but a mod helped fix that problem so now I lose fatigue by sprinting in Oblivion as well :) Cheers, and hope you enjoy the game! God knows I did and still do!

Oh yeah, as for armour customization, there's helmet, cuirass, left pauldron, right pauldron, left gauntlet, right gauntlet, greaves, and boots. You can LITERALLY wear 8 different types of armour if you so choose, which is an impossibility in Oblivion or Morrowind.

My most common character choices are probably as follows:

Race: Imperial (Sometimes Nord)
Gender: Male (always)
Hair: Dark Brown (either short or long)

Major Skills:
Long Sword
Destruction
Speechcraft
Marksman
Medium Armour (Sometimes I go with Light Armour instead, but NEVER Heavy Armour or Unarmoured. Yes, Unarmoured is an option)

Minor Skills
Alchemy
Mercantile
Blacksmithing
Block
Alteration (Learn to FLY! Though sometimes I go with Mysticism so I can capture souls in gems more effectively)

I can't rightly recall the exact number, but with this combination, my Long Sword starts around 50 give or take 5 levels I think. Speechcraft is way up there as well, and Marksman is not too bad at all. Speaking of which, are there crossbows in Oblivion or Skyrim? I don't recall, but they are most certainly in Morrowind, along with throwing knives, darts, and shurikins or whatever they're called. Ninja stars. Sounds kind of lame, but you find enchanted arrows/shurikins/knives somewhat commonly. Adds some magical damage, which helps.

Alright this is basically the second time I'm ending this review, cheers! For those who read the whole damn thing, I hope it didn't bore you too much!

reviewText: Most of you have played or heard about Skyrim and Oblivion. What you may not know is that neither of those games could match the mature tone and sense of mystery and wonder that Morrowind mastered. reviewText: The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind, a classic TES title. This game is hailed as one the greatest TES game by some, nice blast from the past by others. Whilst I haven't got far in the way of story I have certainly gained enough expirirence to talk about it. The first question I asked myself is if this game will hold up to previous TES titles. The answer is, it does, it's over a decade old and can still hold up in comparison to the later titles such as Oblivion and Skyrim in fact, Skyrim had plenty of references to Morrowind (Music from Morrowind soundtrack, Destroying the Dark Brotherhood, random assasination attempt on your life etc.). Morrowind, like the later games, rewards you for exploration, I once found a lovely Nordic Battle Axe (for which I had been searching for for quite some time) in a cave I reluctantly entered. I felt happy with myself for making this choice and made it a rule that I shall walk everwhere on foot because I will likely get rewarded for the extra time spent and I get to admire the scenere (Which whilst outdated graphically, still makes me want to stop and enjoy and plus Graphics isn't the greatest thing about the game). I once found myself looking for a bunch of Thieves held up in a cave with no idea on their exact location. I chanced upon a camp (of sorts) inhabited by three dunmir in robes. I proceeded forward, believing them to be friendly, to which I was blatted in the face by three seperate spells and was nearly killed (me and my friends have taken to calling this expirience TES Z). Overall, Morrowind is a brillaint game with a lovely world and great gameplay (considering it was released a dozen years ago I think we can excuse it on some points as it was grounbreaking for it's time). I would certainly reconmend it to any TES fan or RPG fan.

reviewText:
Where could I possibly begin?

The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind is perhaps the most notorious title within the Elder Scrolls franchise. While the age of Morrowind is more than evident in it's antiquated graphics it's sheer complexity and depth more than make up for any perceived shortcomings. Players seeking literally hundreds of hours of gameplay, exceptional modding capabilities and immense lands to explore will be more than satisfied by purchasing this game.

Downfalls to new players would likely include limited fast travel options, at times overly complex skill selections during character creations and the graphics as mentioned before. Graphics and textures can all be improved with the use of 3rd party mods which have saturated the internet to this very day.

Hardcore Elder Scroll and RPG fans will be sure to enjoy Morrowind.

reviewText: Absolutley fantastic game. My clocked hours is misleading, as i played most of this game during a car ride across the USA, btw. But to the point, this game is beautiful, in many ways. My favorite part is the environment and the atmosphere. Vvardenfel is such a strange place, you feel like your on another planet sometimes. Wandering through the ashlands, trudging through the swamps, or delving into a daedric ruin, there is tons of stuff to explore.  The dark elf culture is so vibrantly displayed, as is their reactions to other cultures. The customs and armors (especially bonemold, i love that stuff) are so peculiar and awesome, its like nothing you'll find elsewhere.  The sounds are great as well. The soundtrack fits perfectly with the game, however it is only 30min long, and the repitition gets a wee bit annoying sometimes.  The thing that i love the most about it is its complexity. This is not an easy game, and you need some knowledge to get through, unlike Skyrim, which was dumbed down for all the console CoD fans (still a great game tho). The leveling system works very well, the combat system does not. Using melee weapons is okay, but magic is freaking impossible. The graphics on this game are amazing, especially for 2002. They impress me even today. All in all, this is a great game. Highly reccomend it.

reviewText:
Short ReviewNote: 100s of hours played during retail release. What you witness before you is hands down one of the greatest games of all time. A stunning masterpiece bearing odd design choices and bugs, but equally cherished for its charm and flaws.

Unless it’s cries of “Absolutely fantastic!”, “Bloody marvellous!” or “♥♥♥♥in’ awesome!” To sum Morrowind up in a single paragraph is a crime against nature. Therefore, please read the rest of this lengthy review!

Kiddie Steam reviewer verdict: “left boat. gave fargoth his ring. went 2 inn. stole magic sword, escaped chasing guards. saw wizard fall frm sky, stole his clothes. rat attked me, so I killd it aftr 50 clicks. ran up mountain, killed by cliff racer. 10/10 wud mountain climb again.”

Long ReviewBack in 2002 Morrowind was bundled freely with my Nvidia Ti4200-8x 128MB. I installed and fired up this game that my friend would just not stop talking about. A 15 year old at the time who disliked RPGs, Morrowind slapped me in the face and revolutionised my gaming experiences forever.

GraphicsHard to believe these graphics were state of the art once upon a time: indeed, this was the first time I’ve seen water shaders used and it blew me away! However the draw distance is miniscule and it’s clear Morrowind was designed this way as using mods to increase the draw distance kills my frame rate on a PC that eats Skyrim + ENBs at a fluid 60fps. Still, I do recommend a draw distance mod because it’s not 2002 anymore and you need to see where you’re bloody going.

Despite the short view, low poly meshes and blurry textures, the graphics themselves are by no means terrible and make the game world feel alive with a healthy organic colour palette, knowing when to dull the scene out or add vibrancy without becoming over saturated. This was before the dawn of post-processing turning everything either ♥♥♥♥ yellow, ♥♥♥♥ brown or losing your contact lenses.

SoundDat menu music, wow. If like me you opened the game for the first time and hear the low drum beats followed by that sweet soothing melody caressing your eardrums, that’s a virgin experience no one can take away from you.

The soundtrack is a collaboration of traditional orchestral instruments, very easy on the ears and sets the mood of the game very well. Thanks to clever and deliberate use of subtle tones, I personally never found the music too repetitive and certain cues would instantly conjure up visions of my previous adventures. Jeremy Soule has outdone himself tenfold and really brings “Soule” into Morrowind, heh.

Sadly, Morrowind seriously lacks in the vocal department, and your journey across Vvardenfall will consists of lines of repeated dialogue from about 5 different actors. Not like other games don’t do this, but you’re expected to read large amounts of text rather than use your ears.

Sound effects are pretty decent, with a mixture of unique and generic FX bundled together. Not ground breaking stuff, but works extremely well in the world of Morrowind.

Character DevelopmentNow here’s where Morrowind truly shines. Unlike most typical RPGs, Morrowind forgoes a strict class-based system in favour of allowing the player to do whatever the hell they please with their character. Be a magic dabbling barbarian or sneaky thief in heavy armour, the game won’t stop you.

Stealth mechanics are governed by skill more than anything else. You can nick a suit of armour right in front of an NPC in broad daylight and he won’t notice, but swipe a handkerchief from the dark room behind him and he’ll instantly become alerted. If it wasn’t clear, light has NO EFFECT whatsoever, so be prepared for a very strange stealth experience. Stealth is still fun though as nearly all my Morrowind characters have been thieves!

Raising your skills occurs from repeated usage of said skill. Whilst ensuring you’re putting at least some elbow grease into levelling up, this system is widely open to exploitation, with well documented cases of repeatedly running up stairs to raise athletics or entering someone’s house and stabbing the ♥♥♥♥er to near death to raise combat skills. And speaking of combat...

CombatThe notorious combat system is Morrowind’s biggest flaw, yet biggest charm. A supposed complex system that involves everything from skill level, fatigue, luck, random dice rolls and other RPG-ish powers that be, it all just boils down to frantically clicking the mouse button so that your 1 out of 20 hits will actually hit the ♥♥♥♥in’ thing – LITERALLY. An extremely illogical and tedious system where your 6ft spear magically misses the girth of a hungry bear, combat will be the bane of your existence during your fledging moments. Still, once you raise your stats to a worthy degree and able to one-shot all who dare stand in your path, the sense of progression from grasshopper to terminator feels VERY satisfactory!

Game WorldThe island of Morrowind truly steals the show. The landscape is so diverse it’s ridiculous, with each region so rich enough it might as well have come from an entirely different game! From the swampy fishing villages in the Bitter Coast region, to the dark looming Red Mountain from the Ashlands, to the twisting architecture of the Telvanni district, to the floating building in Vivec City… Morrowind surprises, delights and surprises every single time, even for veterans commencing their 50th playthrough.

Not many fast travel options available so expect to have to walk everywhere. A bit of a chore at times, but the island actually isn’t terribly large – it just feels that way because of the amount of love and care crafted into it. You will need to take your time with this one and plan for the journey ahead.

As per usual RPG standards you can find all manner of hidden caves, secrets, side quests and lewt. A pretty static gameworld, characters tend to stay in a single spot and all shops are open 24/7 at your convenience. Realistic? No. Beneficial? Yes. Don’t forget that full day and night cycles were rare back then.

All common NPCs share the same batch of (very well written) dialogue, so whilst it’s very handy to get information quick and fast, this results in most NPCs being just walking information booths (or punch bags) devoid of personality. Of course, many many NPCs still have their own unique text, so you’ll still enjoy a good dose of story telling.

Lastly the lore in the game is as thick as tar. Different races, religions, guilds, conflicts... Wanna know the history behind something? Find an in-game book about it. Curious about the conflicts between certain factions? Interview each faction about it, perhaps side with one, with both or none at all.

NotesMorrowind used to crash back in the day. A LOT. I have played it in recent years and noticed much less crashing, however as a golden rule - save early and save often: if the cliff races don’t get ya, the CTDs will.

Since this game is so old, it runs silky smooth on modern hardware, so no issues with optimisation.

As ever, there are thousands of mods to alter your game with, so like or don’t like something: there’s a mod for that.

Final WordsI really couldn’t tell whether Morrowind will appeal to you as a modern gamer, because the unforgettable experience I had of playing it as a teen has permanently blinded me with nostalgia. All I can say is this: Morrowind has left its mark on gamers and the gaming industry. It’s a masterpiece, it’s flawed, it’s epic, it’s fun, it’s frustrating, it’s magical, it’s scary, it’s emotional, it’s weird, it’s… yea.

I guess you need to accept the mechanics and that it’s a product of its time. Whether you like it or not, I do hope you can at least acknowledge the impact it left on the gaming world back in 2002.

reviewText:
*This article is somewhat unfinished. I definitely could add more, and I may update it later. Although, it is comprehensive as-is for a game review.

One of the greatest games I have ever played.

I just want to highlight the skill system here, for some of the good and inherently bad things about it.
The thing about the skill system in Morrowind is that it has many skills and possibilities, but it is solely based on the gods of the RNG. The thing that's so bad about this, is that everything you do is based on a percentage, a number, and a chance or just that sliver of hope as a new character. Which means even if you are an extremely powerful level 50 character, you still have a chance of just completely missing the enemy and doing no damage.

Another thing I see people fail to realise in midst of their nostalgia for this game, is the Fatigue system. There is literally no reason for me not to be able to throw fireballs at people's faces because my Fatigue is low and the chance of casting is significantly lowered. And that's all I'll say about that, it's incredibly aggrevating.

The Graphics in this game- all I can say is that they're extremely dated and about 13 years old. They haven't exactly aged well. But although this game doesn't look terrible, it can still be jarring for a new player to come from Skyrim or Oblivion into this game (Like me...).

The Gameplay of this game is incredible, despite it's odd skill system. It's Classic RPG fundamentals are, in a way, the lifeblood of this game, despite it's oddities. In no other game can you walk up to a slow-moving mudcrab at level 1, completely miss every swing, and get yourself killed. Despite this, you can do anything you want, kill anyone or anything you want, steal, plunder, or even become the Grandmaster of almost every guild. Despite this, the game does NOT hold your hand. You have to work for what you want. Don't have enough gold for that Dreugh Helmet? Go to that dwarven ruin over the hill, kill everything inside, and find the treasures within. This game really captures the scope and expanse you would expect of an entire continent in the world. You can be prancing along in the rolling hills of the grazelands, and the next minute you're in the middle of Molag Amur, in the midst of pools of lava and ash. That being said, it still takes a while for that transition. Even for an old game, the map is huge (And there's much to do in that map!).

The Story is one of the pinnacle of this game. In more recent years, the story has not been bland, per se- but rather, it has been turned into this constant story that the game will try to make you feel rather inclined to stay with until that story has ended. For example, in Skyrim the main story was very heavily forced upon you. They try to create this false sense of urgency" that you just do not find in this game. reviewText:
I love Morrowind. I've played probably around 300 hours of it and there's still lots of unique quests to explore. That being said, if I take off my nostalgia glasses, there are some pretty major flaws that I feel anyone playing it for the first time today should be aware of. Breaking it down:

Cons:
* Combat of all types is boring. Magic/Stealth/Archery/Melee are all essentially reduced to keep-clicking-until-it-dies. On the magic side of things, the spell creation system is fun and there are lots of neat base spells to choose from, but in essence the combat itself is overly simple.
* The leveling system functions fine if you just don't pay attention to it, but optimal leveling is a tedious chore. If you are the type who just can't pass up an opportunity for maximum stat gains, this might be a big detractor.
* The dialogue is text based and most NPCs are just walking lore encyclopedias. The persuasion and bartering systems are laughably simple, and again, boring.
* The graphics haven't aged well, though it does have a strong artistic concept at its core.
* The menu interface is sub-par, but gets the job done.

Pros:
* Exploration is really well rewarded. Everywhere you look there's some small detail that hints at a story, or a unique artifact with interesting properties. Many of the ruins have secret entrances and places that you could easily miss.
* Morrowind does a good job of making you feel like your actions have impact. It could be better, but it is satisfying when factions will hate or love you depending on what you've done, and there are many unique dialog lines based on how famous you are.
* The quests are unique. Sure some of them blend together a little bit, but overall they are NOT just cookie-cutter quests. Most of them give you some insight into the world and how it works, or have some neat little twist.
* You can fly. It seems so trivial but I keep coming back to this as an example of the game's overwhelming freedom. It's fun scrounging around in the early game for limited-use levitation spells or the infamous Scrolls of Icarian Flight which make you jump so high you'll certainly die on your way back down. You start out so weak but there are powerful scrolls and spells to exploit that can change the entire game... the wild variance in the power of the enemies and items you encounter is one of Morrowind's stronger points.
* A final important pro is the modding community. If there are things you don't like about this game, chances are high there's a mod that can change it. In particular, I have a had good luck with graphics mod compilations and just general expansion packs. Of course, modding is not necessarily everyone's cup of tea.

In summary, this game has many great features and in some ways the sense of depth and scale you get when immersed in it is unrivaled by any game since. However, it requires a certain type of gamer, (or a certain amount of modding,) to get past its unpalatable quirks and into the wonderful world beneath.



EDIT: Just going to address a couple points that have come up in the comments.
* Discrepancy in my playtime listed vs what I have on record with Steam. I played Morrowind in 2004 just after the GOTY edition came out, which was before it was on Steam. I later purchased it on Steam because I had lost my physical copy.
* I love Morrowind yet gave it a non-recommendation. I wrote this review for the general gaming public in 2013 and I did not think it would be a good experience for the average 2013 Steam gamer because of the points listed above, hence my non-recommendation.

The newest game in the Elder Scrolls franchise, Morrowind is the largest and most expansive game ever created. With over 40,000 hours of entertainment without the amazing DLC, it'll literally consume your time and poop it out to shame you like the outlander that you are.

You start off being sent to a 'fun camp' from an undisclosed previous location, due to crimes that you have forgotten due to sudden and specific amnesia. After you convince the guards that you have no idea what you've done or why, they let you go, to save you from the punishment of public incineration.

After much trudging about, doing things for drug money, you're finally given the task to eliminate a high-ranking drug lord who has become so burned out on drugs that he thinks he's a god. You have to stab him to death, and then blow up his life's work in order to save yourself.

All in all, Michael Bay's latest game performs excellently, with better visuals than even the Crysis series.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I have only played the three most-recent Elder Scrolls games: Morrowind, Oblivion and Skyrim. I am sadly ignorant on the quality of the earlier installments.

---

Morrowind is my favorite modern Elder Scrolls game. Period.

There are some downsides. Graphically, Morrowind is increasingly dated. It comes from an unfortunately time (early 2000's) in history where full 3D games tried to portray realism without the resources to do so convincingly. Environments are fairly low res. As far as NPCs are concerned, they're not uncanny valley. They're just kind of crappy-looking, and lack the individual daily schedules that NPCs have in later games. Here, they wander within a short range, but people who you encounter outside will forever be standing outside, never to even set foot in their homes. Mechanically, the game can be rough around the edges. In Oblivion and Skyrim, furthering one's combat skill means increased damage. Starting out in Morrowind, low sword skill means you're unlikely to even hit your target when you swing. It's a steep curve, to be sure, and representative of how the game approaches skills and leveling up. Additionally, the quest log -- the game's system for tracking general learned information and info pertaining to specific active or inactive quests -- is unorganized and difficult to work with. It is barely a step above remembering what you're actively doing, and trying not to take up any other tasks until it is completed.

So what really separates Morrowind from later Elder Scrolls games?

The world is large and real. This isn't scandanavia or medieval England. This is a world unlike any other, with giant mushrooms and huge insects. It is interesting, unique, and worth exploring. And explore you will, because there is no fast-travel. The best form of transportation are via specific routes between certain cities -- boats, Mages Guild teleportation, large land beasts, etc. Anything else, be it going to off-the-beaten-path settlements, or simply getting to one of those hub towns, requires hoofing it. It adds a staggering degree of realism that later games stripped away. The world isn't actually larger, but the game presents itself that way. There are more guilds and organizations. More missions for those guilds. More cities, towns, and people. There's an openness to it because the cities aren't walled in, a separate level from the outside.

The player also has a degree of agency that hasn't existed in Elder Scrolls games since. The degree of skill customization is extensive: more kinds of weaponry to specialize in, more kinds of armor, more branches of magic and spells within those branches. The player also has a lot more freedom to affect the world in permanent ways. You actions in one guild will affect other guilds. Everyone can be killed, including quest givers and NPCs integral to the main story. The world is yours to take. Oblivion introduced the concept of player-bought houses. No such game-sanctioned method exists in Morrowind. Instead, acquiring a house involves using your freedom. You could find a house that appears abandoned and move in, or you could find a nice house, murder the occupant, dispose of their body, and make it yours. There aren't items that are free to take and items that constitute stealing. There's just items, and you can steal them.

The NPCs that inhabit Morrowind offer vastly more variety. With brief exceptions, the game has no voice acting. All dialogue is simply textual, and different personalities can be revealed through the text of their dialogue. Every NPC doesn't have the same voice, creating the impression of world populated by artificial clones. This fact alone almost certainly influenced the rest of the game, because it meant that something as simple as adding another Thieves Guild quest didn't involve more voice and audio work.

This, in a way, describes the game as a whole. It's clear that, when the game was being developed, there was a lot more freedom to add content and run wild when developing the game. It bleeds into almost every aspect of the game. It's not as smooth, nor as pretty, as later installments, but it's a world worth exploring,

reviewText:
I started with Skyrim and wanted to see where this crazy Elder Scrolls open world stuff really got started. I was not disappointed when I started playing Morrowind. The game is a bit dated, graphically and gameplay-wise, but I think it offers a lot of fun times and interesting ways to play.

Pros:
-text based dialogue gives more information and options that aren't limited by voiceovers
-intricate magic and leveling systems allow for truly amazing customization
-main quest is really interesting so far (I'm about 30 hours in)
-the lore is vast, making it seem like a living, breathing world despite the aged mechanics
-the creature designs are simply amazing... creepy and intimidating...
-varied map makes the world seem even bigger than it is (in-game fast travel options add to immersion too)
-in game strip club with some swag moves
-score by the same guy who did Skyrim's soundtrack (and SW KOTOR and Bounty Hunter)

Cons:
-lack of tutorials means you have to either experiment for endless hours or get help online with gameplay mechanics
-some stock dialogue gets repetitive
-soundtrack is limited... you will hear the same explore tracks over and over again
-graphics are dated (though I really enjoy the oldschool feel)

reviewText:
The Gold Standard of open world RPG. The mother of all RPG games to come after it. Morrowind revolutionized the idea of an open world game. There is depth to the world that is unparalleled in both games released before this as well as afterwards. The game is dated, so there is something to be said about how smoothly the game runs and looks and feels, but there are many mods that can be used to remedy those issues (http://www.nexusmods.com/morrowind/mods/36945/?).

This game begins with you as a prisoner. No history, you can become whatever you want to be. You can create a character who does anything you want. The depth of the character development allows you to become anything you want. You can choose follow a pre-built class chosen from a list of 21 including classes such as: sorceror, thief, and warrior. Or you can be something new and creative by creating your own class. If you want (and I did this), you can be a walking tank with a two handed battleaxe wearing plate armour imbued with the blood of demons. You can choose to be one of one of ten races, each with their own characteristics, each with their stereotypes that generate responses unique to that race from NPCs. You can even choose to become a vampire or (with the bloodmoon expansion included in the Game of the Year edition) werewolf!This means you will have a unique experience in your game that nobody else has quite experienced.

While the character creation system is very powerful, it can be confusing for a starting player. The key is you don't have to worry about it. The system has very specific things you can do to optimize your character, but you can enjoy the game just as well without employing those strategies.

In playing this game, you find yourself planted in a world, complete with history, religion, science, and anything else you would expect and more. You can find books with conflicting religions. You can worship demons known as daedra. You can read about Vivec ascending to godhood and the religion surrounding them. There are several religious texts in the game that you can read. It is quite a project to learn about the world, sometimes I wonder if I know more about the Elder Scrolls universe or the outside world.

The province of Morrowind is in a time of peril. The longstanding religion of worshipping AlmSiVi, the tribunal, is wavering. An old enemy is rising again. You have complete control over what you do with the world. You can completely ignore the world's issues and go to set out to just explore caves, crypts, and other areas on your own. You can go join a guild and rise through those ranks, You can even kill people who are essential to saving the world. You can save the world, or you can just as well doom it. The game is whatever you want it to be.

This game is the gold standard of RPG for a reason and all current open world RPGs are based off of this amazing game. If you enjoy any open world RPG,  it is a must to come back to the roots of the genre and play the amazing game that really started it all.

reviewText:
Fantastical adventure with an enormous amount of detail and attention. I've been playing it throughout the years, since it first released on Xbox back in Spring of 2002.

You have a huge, carefully-constructed open world to discover with dozens upon dozens of unmarked caves and dungeons and ruins to explore. Hidden easter eggs and references scattered throughout :0

Extensive and thought out skill system. Customize your character into whatever you want. A rouge that favors spears and uses paralysis spells and wears medium armor. A mage that focuses on alteration to bend the environment to their will, while also specializing in sneak to steal anything not bolted to the floor. Splendid combinations!

Levitation as well. Don't feel like climbing or walking around a giant mountain? Drink or use a levitation spell and you'll soon be soaring through the skies... with cliff racers D:

Two other expansion packs, Bloodmoon and Tribunal, further expand upon the story and offer new locations, powerful items and other goodies. Definitely well worth the time to play through those. I quite like Tribunal as my favorite =]


And, of course, there are the hundreds of mods available, if you don't quite like the vanilla game in all it's low-resolution meshed-together glory. Make it look like an upgraded Oblivion if you so choose <3

reviewText:
Morrowind isn't necessarily the greatest game ever made, but as a work of art, it's nearly unmatched. No other game I've played has introduced me to a world so unique and compelling. It's not the writing or the gameplay that does it, but the design of it.

A few things were present in Morrowind to aid this that no later Elder Scrolls game had, and they suffered for it; the complete lack of radar, the journal system that let you forget about quests you didn't care about, the ability to kill any NPC and the ability to levitate. The Elder Scrolls series at its core, to me anyway, is about discovery. It's about being thrown into a vast open world with something new around every corner, and the freedom to get lost.

Morrowind does that better than any game I know. Walking its roads now feels like home to me, and that lonely title theme is sometimes enough for me to cry.

reviewText: Featuring graphics that were cutting edge in its day, Morrowind represented a return to the open world style of previous Elder Scrolls games like Daggerfall and Arena after two lackluster attempts by Bethesda to use the world in a thoroughly linear style, Battlespire and Redguard. While the look of the game was fantastic when it was released, Morrowind has the smallest game world of a true Elder Scrolls game and it takes some thorough exploring just to get a handle on the unique nature of this region in Tamriel and the grave threat facing its inhabitants. There's a wide variety of quests you can complete and a solid variety of guilds to consider joining, but Morrowind can be somewhat difficult to find entertaining these days due to the age of its graphics engine and the more than minor detail that almost no characters are voiced. Neither is the fault of Bethesda when you consider the limitations of CD-ROMs and hard drives of its time. I'll definitely say Morrowind was a step in the right direction for the Elder Scrolls series, but sadly no where near the resounding success that Skyrim would be a decade later. 2 1/2 stars out of 4.

reviewText:
Perhaps the best RPG ever made. Graphics are a bit out dated, but there are mods for that. I recommend Morrowind Overhaul 3.0. It will set up most things automatically, and then let you set specific things that you want. It breathes life back into one of my favorite games.

Don't be fooled by newer Elder Scrolls games such as Oblivion and Skyrim. This game is difficult to start up. It's unforgiving. You may die in the first cave. Don't give up though. Explore, gather loot, and learn how to best use your fatigue.

There is no hand holding in this game. No quest markers, no fast travel (unless you use the town to town system and even that costs gold), and enemies don't level with you. You can wander into zones where you have no business being.

I can not recommend this game enough. It's a masterpiece.

reviewText: A good game, but not without flaws. The music, world, and plot are all top-notch. The only problem is the game itself is well, a bit of a chore. The combat, frankly, is quite awful, as it lacks both the tactical appeal of a top-up party based western RPG like Baldur's Gate or Dragon Age and the fluid action gameplay of a proper action-RPG like Skyrim. You just click repeatedly and hope you hit. Like all Elder Scrolls games, you level up what you use, but the way Morrowind does it can lead to some mildly ridiculous metagaming. (eg: Oh dear, I'd better avoid jumping for the rest of the level or my Acrobatics stat will get ahead of my Short Blades stat.) I would prefer Morrowind's multiple attributes such as strength, speed, intelligence, and willpower to Skyrim's three, health, stanima, and magica, if the sole purpose in every stat in Morrowind was not to raise your health, stanima, or magica, or to raise damage/resistance, which Skyrim did via skills and perks. For example, your character's dialogue isn't any different if he's got an Intelligence of 60 or 30, so why bother keeping count? In Dragon Age, you got unique dialoge options based on your cunning stat, and low intelligence characters in Neverwinter Nights talked reel dum liek thiz. If the only purpose of Intelligence is to get more magica, then honestly, they were streamlining, not dumbing down when they got rid of it in favor of the Magica stat directly. While exploration is much touted, enemies aren't leveled, and as such, may be ridiculously easy or hard depending on the area. This is, of course, more realistic than enemies always being just tough enough for you, and wouldn't be a problem if leveling didn't feel like such a damned grind. To be brutally honest, there are times it feels like a MMO in a vacant world. Other things touted as perks" by Morrowind afficianados may be tinted a bit by nostalgia as well

reviewText: Epic  game with tons of freedom. Probably the truest RPG Bethesda has ever made. If you can get a handle on the somewhat challenging character growth system, enjoy a game with older graphics, and put up with a few odd bugs, it's one of the better entries into the TES series. Main questline good and quite lengthy (30+ hours). With plenty of factions to join and interesting side quests it will keep you busy for weeks or even months. If you can, get the GOTY edition; Tribunal and Bloodmoon are both fantastic and Skyrim's Dragonborn DLC will make a lot more sense. Only minor complaints would have to be 1) shields auto-block which makes combat feel a lot less skillful; 2) it's impossible to retrieve arrows from the environment which makes arrows a scarce commodity. I was afraid to use my good arrows for basically the entire game because of this; 3) fast travel is only from city to city, which means there is a lot of walking involved. Not necessarily a horrible thing, because there are some cool random NPC encounters along roads, but it does slow the game's pace down a bit and it would be nice to be able to fast travel from the map screen like you can in Oblivion and Skyrim. Overall though it's a great game, especially if you're a TES fan. 9.5/10

reviewText:
This game, simply put? My childhood in a nutshell. I was psyched to see that it was on Steam, after my obnoxiously long playthrough of the Xbox version. I didn't know what to think of the game when I first started, to be perfectly honest. That day my brother threw it to me and said he didn't like it, I took it upon myself to learn about this game and see what it was about.

Boy, was I in for an adventure.

I don't think I had ever heard of the Elder Scrolls series before I picked up this game. I took it as one of those silly, few hour adventure games that I could simply blow through and not care what was going on. The moment I stepped off that boat at Seyda Neen...yeah, I was DEAD wrong. I immediately jumped into the story with a hybrid thief/warrior build Argonian that I took it upon myself to name 'Trogdor,' due to my at-the-time obsession with Homestar Runner, and the plot literally sucked me in. I could play this game for HOURS and never get bored. Just exploring the environment and doing the main questline was enough to keep me interested. The characters were definitely memorable than I thought they would be, and the story really made me wonder why my brother had tossed it aside so quickly.

One of the points I have to make is about the combat system. Since this game was the prequel to Oblivion, it's to be expected. Back then, I really didn't care about weapon accuracy being based on your weapon proficiency, but when you're constantly exchanging blows with your opponent, you can't help but rage when you only hit about 10% of the time. That is, until you've got about 70-80 in your preferred weapon type. Jumping back from Skyrim or Oblivion...it may be a bit difficult to adjust from being able to land every hit on your opponent at level 1. Enemy movement is also a little bit clunky, but it just takes a bit of time to get used to.

The endgame had to have been one of my most favorite parts of the game, especially when you're mowing down enemies with more powerful enchanted weapons and spells. It may become a bit unbalanced, but, come on, you're the Nerevarine. Does it really matter? The extra content and locations provided by the DLC also add to the experience, especially scaling the enemies to a more comfortable and somewhat challenging level.

All in all though, I'd definitely recommend this game for anybody looking to get into an engrossing RPG with branching questlines and a memorable world. For those of you that prefer a more...streamlined experience, you can't go wrong with the many graphics and combat system overhaul mods that are out there. Give it a try, see if you like it.

reviewText:
Morrowind and Oblivion are probably two of my favourite, no my favourite games of all time. If Oblivion and Skyrim are great, this is a masterpiece. It does have flaws however, which we will touch on later. You probably think my opinion is tainted by nostalgia. Well it isn't. I picked this game up in 2014, after playing Oblivion and Skyrim, beat the main questline with no mods and loved every moment of it. It doesn't speak to everyone, though. Some will hate things like the lack of fast travel or quest markers, the huge map, the complicated plotline, unforgiving creatures, unfamiliar environments and cliffracers, but others will thrive on them.

But let's get into the features. This episode of TES is set on the Island of Vvardenfell, a land full of of ash, dunmer, daedric ruins and cliffracers. Probably the most unique map I've seen. To the south there is swamplands, governed by House Hlaalu, to the east we have the grasslands of House Telvanni and to the north the ashlands of House Redoran. There is also the Island of Soltheim (Yes, the one from Dragonborn) and the capital city of Mounhold. The game has the same ten races of the other games in the series (Dunmer, Altmer, Bosmer, Redguard, Nord, Orc, Imperial, Breton, Khajit and Argonian), and allows you to create your own character from scratch. You can be a warrior, a wizard, an archer (I don't recommend archery) and more. One of the things that makes Morrowind shine is the character development. Unlike Skyrim, where within about 5 hours you're a badass known throughout the lands, Morrowind took me 48 hours to become that. At the start you will be laughed at and mocked by the native Dunmer, but by the end of the main quest you'll be a hero 10 times as epic as the Dragonborn.

Speaking of main quests, Morrowinds story is great. You'll start off doing jobs for the Blades, but gradually you will learn of an ancient prophecy, and how you may be the fabled 'Nerevarine'. At the end, it will still be uncertain whether you really are Nerevar reborn or not. No matter what you do, you won't pleaser everyone. You will meet all kinds of characters, all with different beliefs. While many NPCs are basically made of peanuts, the different groups shine through. The Empire technically rules Morrowind, and aids you on your quest. House Hlaalu are peaceful with the Empire, but still Dunmer at heart. House Telvanni hate the empire, and stay to themselves in their mushroom towers to the east. House Redoran live in the north, in odd shell houses. The ashlanders are the native tribes of Vvardenfell, believing in ancient prophecies of Nerevarine, but are being prosecuted by the Tribunal Temple.

As always, I recommend learning some basic lore before starting. Take a look at this series https://www.youtube.com/user/ShoddyCast , or read some ingame books.

Morrowind is much more like a table-top RPG then the rest of the series. Certain parts will require a little imagination, for example, instead of having a cutscene take place during a disturbing dream, you will read a textbox. Or instead of voice acted conversations, you will have to read.

The game still has a strong cult following 12 years after its release, with many lore sites, D&D style RPs and an active steam community, and its easy to see why. If you find the game too hard, there is a ton of mods to improve that. Or you could just stick with it for 10 hours or so like I did, and eventually you'll enjoy it.

However there are some constroversial negatives (Some find them positives) such as: No voice acting, unfamiliar environment, lack of voice acting, cardboard NPCs, harsh environment, odd style, no fast travel or quest markers, bad journal system (Not really a problem, the GOTY fixes this), dice roll combat, confusing story, bad graphics"

reviewText: This is the defining game of the series, Oblivion and Skyrim, (both incredible, fantastic, amazing games), are really just simplified, almost dumbed down versions on THIS game, however, exicuted in a really great way. Morrowind allows freedom that the two games that followed just cant replicate. Spells, and enchanting bassically allow you to create things so powerfull, you would think it shouldnt even be allowed in the game, BUT, you can only achieve such things if you are smart enough to figure out how. Which brings me to my next point, everything in the game is layed out for you, the only things holding you back are skill levels. Once you get high enough levels, you can litterally make a spell to give you the abbility to fly, and shoot nukes at what ever the ♥♥♥♥ you want. You cant buy a house, but that doesnt mean you cant break into some dark elfs manor, kill him, and make his house your's. you can then drop your items where you want them to display them, tons of artifacts to collect. Bottom line, this game is very challenging, it sepparates the real gamers from the posers, the men from the children, It requires you to use youre head once, think about things, it doesnt force you to explore, it doesnt force you to talk to people, but if you dont, and you are lazy about it, this game will eat you alive, and you will be stuck. you literally have to LEARN.. you HAVE to learn, the lore, the skills, the weapons, the artifacts, the land, how to fight and survive. it makes the game very special, to me at the very least. You cant just bull ♥♥♥♥ your way through, quests are hard, there are no quest markers, dialouge is all text based. if you kill the wrong person you can doom the world which makes it impposible for you to finish the game or complete certain quests. the sad thing is, that its hard to get into this game these days, the graphics are dated for sure, the combat has some major flaws..  but if you can get past that, this game truely is brilliant, its fantastic, its simply more than words can describe. there is so much content, that im not sure any single person on this planet knows every little thing of information, item, or quest. If you think you can handle all of that.. then buy it, dont think, just do it. Oblivion, and Skyrim wouldnt exsist if this game wasnt so incredible, thats a fact.\n\nEdit: i will note that i only have 13 hours in this game on steam, but all of my play time comes from xbox when it was first ported. i was also only in 7th and 8th grade when i spent all my time playing this game.

reviewText: The best 'modern' Elder Scrolls game by a long shot, and a rude awakening for anyone whose introduction to ES was Oblivion or Skyrim. You begin as literally a nobody, born under a certain sign to uncertain parents, released from the Imperial City's prison under questionable circumstances and thrust into a world where nobody likes you and everything will probably try to kill you. There is no magical arrow in the sky showing you where to go, and even the smallest of encounters can be deadly. Fast travel exists only in the form of paid transports, running everywhere will render you too exhausted to fight effectively, untrained spells will fail and unpracticed attacks will miss. But this is what makes Morrowind special; a truly fantastic, alien, landscape, real challenges, complex plotlines requiring real choices and tests of loyalty and skill instead of 'follow the magic arrow to the next cutscene'.\n\n11/10.
