reviewText:
The game that pushed the open world western RPGs to the next level.

Pros

Incredibly detailed and unusual fantasy world
Original leveling system
Incredible modding potential
Best sky representation in it's time, especially the night sky
Music, sound effects, voices
Completely open world from the get-go
Great main story
Lots of quests to do
Lots of factions and guilds to choose from
Weather effects (especially ash storms) adds a lot of uniqueness to the enviroment
Almost limitless potential in spellcrafting and enchanting
Limitless character developement potential
Large amount of weapons and armor to choose from
Still runs fine after all these years
Low HDD space requirement
Tutorial is short but tells you everything you need to know
You can become a vampire or a werewolf
Cons

If you are not the patient type, travelling can be a chore
No day and night cycle for 99% of the NPCs
NPCs are mostly static and do not travel at all
Lack of mounts
Lack of player housing
Fighting mechanics are clunky and barely exist
Cannot fight and cast spells at the same time
Character creation have very few options
Leveling has some issues
Character animaton is a mixed bag
Useless 3rd person view option
What is this game?

Morrowind is a first-person view based, open world, non-linear western style RPG released in 2002 for PC and later for the original Xbox. This is the 3rd main title in the Elder Scrolls series, the first fully 3D game and the first with 100% hand crafted enviroment. This version includes both official expansion packs released to the game. While the game is excellent by itself, it is highly modable and let's you upgrade almost all aspect of it. In my opinion it's significance can only be compared to GTA 3 and Final Fantasy VII in their respective genres. A must have experience for RPG fans everywhere around the world, highly recommened. NOTE: There are independent content patches for this game and I'm not sure if they are included in this version. These can be found on the Bethesda website.

Long review

First of all sorry about this 'short' review, I had to cut the review in half and redo it completely to fit it in this tiny space. Also this is my first review, so bare with me. Let's get on with it then. Let me start with the beginning, character creation and tutorial. You start as a prisoner released to freedom by the emperor. For what reason? That you'll have to find out in the main quest. Sadly the game don't have too many options coming to character creation, it's very simplistic. Rather focus your attention to your race, class and birthsign: these will determine how powerful your character will be at the beginning. Why just the beginning? Because there is no limitation in skill progression in this game. You can max out everything. To help out newcomers I give a nice melee character combo: Redguard - Knight - The lady. The first building serves as the tutorial area, so examine everything you find, or just skip it entirely. In this game nothing is forced on you. After you got your relaese papers and fee, you are free in every possible respect. While you got pointers to where to go first, you are not forced to, you are set to explore the island of Vvardenfell. At first it seems like just a regular fantasy setting, except for maybe the giant bug you see right next to the village. Yes, that is just the beginning.  As you venture into the island the first thing that stands out are the giant, 10 meters high mushrooms in the grasslands. And further traveling in the island there is nothingness. Vegetation gone and vulcanic ash everywhere. You bump into ancient ruins of Dwemer, Daedric and Dunmer in origin, far from being abandoned. You can find cities made of giant crab shells and magicly altered mushrooms. Your travels will be slowed by ash storms, thunderstorm and bandits. But you'll have to walk, as you have limited ways of transportation in this game. Not all is hostile to you tho. You can find several towns and cities with merchants and inns to sleep in, but most importantly you can find guilds and factions to join. They not just give you additional quests, but they will provide discounted services for you and additional storyline . Speaking of quests, there is of course a main story in the game, which I don't want to spoil too much, is a great epic journey of a prisoner becoming one of the empire's blades agents and at the end ascending to godhood. The main story is about politics, religion, revenge and redemption. You are going to set things right in this land. As your adventure goes forward you will learn a lot about this land and the empire from NPCs and books. Books are also good for leveling your skills, which is mandatory, as this game is all about skills. Skills can go from 0 to 100, representing your chance to succeed in use of given skill. This is important, as the game doesn't make it a secret that everything you do is based on those hidden dice rolls and skill chances. There are no mini games here, even your sword swing is just a start of a dice roll. Skill are also important in leveling up your charater as there is no XP in this game. Instead you have to level 10 major or minor skills to level your character. And when you do, you can increase 3 of your attributes. You can add a multiplier to those attribute levels by leveling skills governed by that attribute. While character creation is simple and hard to do unique characters, the itemisation is very extensive. You can choose from several armor sets and weapon types. If you do not prefer weapons, there is a huge selections of spells to choose from. Even better, you can create your own spell. You can also create magical weapons and potions in the game. Voice acting is good in the game, even if the game is not fully voice acted. Every race has it's unique voice in the game. The music is excellent, composed by the one and only Jeremy Soule. While listening to the nice relaxing medieval melodies traveling the wilderness, it can quick turn to a battle chant when you got attacked. Outside of the game world one of the most important aspect is modding. This game can be modded by almost any way you want, or the engine lets you to. Glitches can be patched, graphical fidelity can be upgraded, new stuff can be added to the game. You can make this game feel and handle so much better if your are not satisfied with it's original ways. And there are some things to address here. The leveling system need some tweaking or complete overhaul. Character animation is bad for some races. Characters can use some more polygons just as better textures. A whole graphical overhaul is also can be on the table, especially the viewing distance. Player housing is completely missing from the game just like mounts. NPCs are few and very static with missing day/night cycles, you can change that too.

Conclusion

Even if the game has several faults, it is nothing short of an ambitious project succeeded. The game has a unique feeling to it, loneliness is weightet heavily on your shoulders as you traverse the vulcanic wasteland of the island or it's catacombs. As you progress through the game and a greater evil force your hand to act, you slowly find a purpose and a goal, even the gods starts to smile on you. It can take 100s of hours of your life easily with one character, not to mention more. I hope I've encouraged you to try this or any of the Elder Scrolls games, they are great experiences. Also, if you are looking for the previous games, you can download the Elder Scrolls 1-2 for FREE from Bethesda.

Feel free to comment and send me messages. Good gaming everyone!

reviewText:
Morrowind and Oblivion are probably two of my favourite, no my favourite games of all time. If Oblivion and Skyrim are great, this is a masterpiece. It does have flaws however, which we will touch on later. You probably think my opinion is tainted by nostalgia. Well it isn't. I picked this game up in 2014, after playing Oblivion and Skyrim, beat the main questline with no mods and loved every moment of it. It doesn't speak to everyone, though. Some will hate things like the lack of fast travel or quest markers, the huge map, the complicated plotline, unforgiving creatures, unfamiliar environments and cliffracers, but others will thrive on them.

But let's get into the features. This episode of TES is set on the Island of Vvardenfell, a land full of of ash, dunmer, daedric ruins and cliffracers. Probably the most unique map I've seen. To the south there is swamplands, governed by House Hlaalu, to the east we have the grasslands of House Telvanni and to the north the ashlands of House Redoran. There is also the Island of Soltheim (Yes, the one from Dragonborn) and the capital city of Mounhold. The game has the same ten races of the other games in the series (Dunmer, Altmer, Bosmer, Redguard, Nord, Orc, Imperial, Breton, Khajit and Argonian), and allows you to create your own character from scratch. You can be a warrior, a wizard, an archer (I don't recommend archery) and more. One of the things that makes Morrowind shine is the character development. Unlike Skyrim, where within about 5 hours you're a badass known throughout the lands, Morrowind took me 48 hours to become that. At the start you will be laughed at and mocked by the native Dunmer, but by the end of the main quest you'll be a hero 10 times as epic as the Dragonborn.

Speaking of main quests, Morrowinds story is great. You'll start off doing jobs for the Blades, but gradually you will learn of an ancient prophecy, and how you may be the fabled 'Nerevarine'. At the end, it will still be uncertain whether you really are Nerevar reborn or not. No matter what you do, you won't pleaser everyone. You will meet all kinds of characters, all with different beliefs. While many NPCs are basically made of peanuts, the different groups shine through. The Empire technically rules Morrowind, and aids you on your quest. House Hlaalu are peaceful with the Empire, but still Dunmer at heart. House Telvanni hate the empire, and stay to themselves in their mushroom towers to the east. House Redoran live in the north, in odd shell houses. The ashlanders are the native tribes of Vvardenfell, believing in ancient prophecies of Nerevarine, but are being prosecuted by the Tribunal Temple.

As always, I recommend learning some basic lore before starting. Take a look at this series https://www.youtube.com/user/ShoddyCast , or read some ingame books.

Morrowind is much more like a table-top RPG then the rest of the series. Certain parts will require a little imagination, for example, instead of having a cutscene take place during a disturbing dream, you will read a textbox. Or instead of voice acted conversations, you will have to read.

The game still has a strong cult following 12 years after its release, with many lore sites, D&D style RPs and an active steam community, and its easy to see why. If you find the game too hard, there is a ton of mods to improve that. Or you could just stick with it for 10 hours or so like I did, and eventually you'll enjoy it.

However there are some constroversial negatives (Some find them positives) such as: No voice acting, unfamiliar environment, lack of voice acting, cardboard NPCs, harsh environment, odd style, no fast travel or quest markers, bad journal system (Not really a problem, the GOTY fixes this), dice roll combat, confusing story, bad graphics"

reviewText:
I was playing this game, before Steam was a thing and 50 GB storage was awesome.
The gameplay is a little clunky, the AI very heavy on the Artificial, not that much on the Intelligence, the mechanics might feel a little clunky and there is no real balance in the game.
Still, this game had and still has, one of the best most intriguing fantasy worlds ever, interresting adventures at every turn, a gripping story (both main and many of the side-missions), epic weapons, an fantastic alien world and a great atmosphere.
It is also made to be modded, and people have been adding extra things to this fantastic piece of gaming history for over 10 years, so odds are, that what ever it is you think the game needs, it is out there.
I do not know exactly how many hours I have put into this fantastic gem of a fantasy game, but my estimate is around 700-1000 hours all in all, and I still find new things in it, from time to time.

reviewText:
Another game I found very fun by Bethesda Softworks. The infamous 'do whatever the ♥♥♥♥ you want' or an open-world RPG game from the early 2000s.This game deserves its' GOTY award.

This game takes place at the 3rd era on the Elder Scrolls' world of Tamriel. You are a prisoner, being released in an island called Vvardenfell, located in Morrowind, the home of the Dunmers, or the dark elves. From there, you decide your own fate, whether becoming the savior of Tamriel or being a petty bandit, it's totally up to you!

Okay, aestethically, it doesn't look pretty impressive by today's standards (well obviously, being a game made from 2003). They did gave it a try on giving water movements and its' damp, tropical enviroment can be felt from looking the meshes and textures. It's pretty good as well. Sound, it's a bit too random (e.g. when fighting some creatures that uses bites for attacks, it sounds like you were punched, and if it missed, it's like missing a thrust/blow). The music in this game is a bit more memorable than the other successors ,because ambience, dungeon, and towns used the same set of music all over again.

Compared to the other successors of the game, TES4 and Skyrim, this game is FAR more immersive than the 2 of them. For example, we're talking about marksman weapons. Morrowind has everything (both thrown and archery weapons exists, which made the game's universe is a bit inconsistent, but it is a good idea after all). Next, fatigue/stamina bar (green bar) affects most of your actions, such as lockpicking, hitting stuffs, casting spells. And a Mount and Blade-ish combat styles (directions affect the damage of your weapons, such as katanas deal better damage  when swung sidewards, etc). And yeah, you would not be able to freely roam like in both skyrim and oblivion (fast travel), so, backtracking is a running theme on the game. Please do note that NPCs has fixed levels and items (meaning that you can get a full set of the best armor ingame, while being a low level character).

TL;DR here are some pros and cons:

+ Immersive world
+ Decent graphics for its' time
+ Many weapon types and variants (broadswords, spears, halberds, axes)
+ You can basically do whatever you want (ignoring the main quest and killing essential NPCs)

- Imbalanced (fixed levels, making early game really tough to get through on some classes)
- Primitive combat system (still using the dodge factor, despite being an FPS RPG)

This is my final verdict for this game,
8.5/10

Overall, it's a good game for any diehard TES fans and dont mind a little challenge from outrageously hard enemies.

reviewText:
Skyrim 3: Morrow, I I MEAN ELDER SCROLLS...

This game is pretty good for what it costs, but to be fair this game is kinda puny in Skyrim's huge shadow, but I won't be comaring this to Skyrim because this came out in 2003.  Gameplay wise it's not bad.  I feels like the weapons and armor you use give some personality to your play style, and there is a large array of weapons anddd armor.  I do especially like that there is no beginning mission that wastes 20-30 minutes every time you start a new game.  The world is most certainly a large and open land just waiting to be discovered.  But I can't praise this game with the problems that you do face, and all the things I mentioned already do have some problems within the good.

The world, while expansive, feels confined to the path that is presented to you.  It never feels like you can go off the path, which makes all the area in between towns feel very dull and hollow.  Everytime that I came across a dungeon or a cave I would feel this overwelming joy of discovery, that would soon be lost seeing as all the dungeons are small, especially for the small amount of them there even are.  The combat is not very good because you hardly ever hit the target unless you are in their face and then you might just land a hit, and I am pretty sure that each hit only deals damage if you have some stamina which takes for ever to recharge.  The controls are the worst seeing as each button has a seperate funtion, which means you'll have about thirty keys in use for every thing and often get lost in your keyboard.  This also most definitly ties into the iffy combat.

The functions and game modes that are in Morrowind are as expected, the open world and beautiful (I'll be it polygonal) that are home to your custom avatar, but the game does also have a very nice soundtrack.  Every track is full of magic and wonder that gets you in the mood for an adventure, and they melt from note to note perfectly, ESPECIALLY the opening theme.

I usually would make a section for the basic layout of the story here, but the beauty of this game is that it gives you no story, which leaves you to do everything that YOU want to do.

This game would be perfect in my opinion if all the problems with the controls where fixed and there were maybe a few more dungeons, but everytime that I load up this game, I hear that theme and I makes me calm and ready for any challenges that face my way.
So in conclusion, my final rating for this game is a 6/10, probably 10/10 if not for so many problems.

reviewText:
Having put 80 hours into the PC version and at least 100 into the Xbox 360 version of Skyrim, I found it hard at first to get over the combat mechanics of Morrowind. The best way I could describe Morrowind's combat is that it is similar to most JRPGs, but in first person and in real-time. When you first pick up this game, I assure you that you will hate its combat. Don't give up on it. As you progress through the game, raising your skills and getting better gear, it will get easier. Eventually it will make perfect sense.

As for the story, I loved it. It was interesting throughout the whole thing and the Tribunal DLC quest line is a great compliment to it. I would highly recommend finishing the main quest, then Tribunal, then Bloodmoon. Tribunal acts as a sort of epilogue to the main story. Bloodmoon doesn't relate to the main story much at all, but it gets hard quick.

Overall, I give this game a 9.5/10

reviewText: I've found Morrowind to be the most enjoyable, immersive, and rewarding game in the Elder Scrolls franchise, and this is coming from someone who played both Oblivion and Skyrim before Morrowind. Unlike newer games in the series, this game is an old-school CRPG that pulls no punches; map markers are nonexistent, fast travel is only possible through in-game transportations systems (silt strider ports, mages guilds, boats, etc), almost every game mechanic is based on a 'dice roll' of sorts (this is why you'll miss nearly every sword swing in the beginning), and enemies/gear in no way scale to the player's level. Make no mistake, this is a game that will absolutely kick your ♥♥♥ for the first 10-15 hours on a first-time playthrough, but if you have the patience and are willing to invest a decent amount of time into your character build, I think you'll find an extremely rewarding experience at the heart of Morrowind.\n\nNote: I higly recommend using Morrowind Overhaul if you want to get the most out of your experience. It increases the visual fidelity of the game drastically and allows you to tweak certain game mechanics to your liking.

reviewText:
I remember the first time I died: trekking from Seyda Neen on foot haphazardly through Vvardenfell. Down from the sky, some flying lizard stabbed me with its tail and I was done.

I've been hooked ever since.

Don't be fooled--- I have thousands of hours invested in this game, having played it on-and-off since I first got it for Christmas in 2003 on xbox; from xbox to pc-cd, then to Steam. It has held up as my favorite game of all time.

Morrowind--- more specifically Vvardenfell--- is a strange and unforgiving world; you will spend many frustrating hours just trying to figure it all out, and many more before the feeling comes that this place is just as much your home as it is theirs.

If you don't know what you're doing, this is the most difficult game you'll find. If you do know what you're doing, it's the easiest--- and still the most fun.

Yes, there are balancing issues, yes there are exploitable features (not counting glitches, but the mechanic itself) and yes there are ways of becoming overpowered." And I still enjoy myself all these years later finding ways to make myself unstoppable in record time or wealthy beyond measure at level one; or pushing it as far as it can go late game.

The combat has also been criticized (my brothers are always making fun of the corny woosh sound of my weapon "missing" even though it clearly made contact with the enemy). I found the combat logic of Morrowind rewarding with the satisfaction of learning how to use a class of weapon you've been wanting to try out--- especially at a higher level when you think you've seen it all. One moment you've pigeon-holed yourself into sword play
hoursPlayed:
and suddenly you're knocking enemies to the floor with Veloth's Judgment.

But enough defending what noobs protest--- onto Morrowind's irrefutable triumphs.

The game's story is as beautiful

reviewText:
Skyrim 3: Morrow, I I MEAN ELDER SCROLLS...

This game is pretty good for what it costs, but to be fair this game is kinda puny in Skyrim's huge shadow, but I won't be comaring this to Skyrim because this came out in 2003.  Gameplay wise it's not bad.  I feels like the weapons and armor you use give some personality to your play style, and there is a large array of weapons anddd armor.  I do especially like that there is no beginning mission that wastes 20-30 minutes every time you start a new game.  The world is most certainly a large and open land just waiting to be discovered.  But I can't praise this game with the problems that you do face, and all the things I mentioned already do have some problems within the good.

The world, while expansive, feels confined to the path that is presented to you.  It never feels like you can go off the path, which makes all the area in between towns feel very dull and hollow.  Everytime that I came across a dungeon or a cave I would feel this overwelming joy of discovery, that would soon be lost seeing as all the dungeons are small, especially for the small amount of them there even are.  The combat is not very good because you hardly ever hit the target unless you are in their face and then you might just land a hit, and I am pretty sure that each hit only deals damage if you have some stamina which takes for ever to recharge.  The controls are the worst seeing as each button has a seperate funtion, which means you'll have about thirty keys in use for every thing and often get lost in your keyboard.  This also most definitly ties into the iffy combat.

The functions and game modes that are in Morrowind are as expected, the open world and beautiful (I'll be it polygonal) that are home to your custom avatar, but the game does also have a very nice soundtrack.  Every track is full of magic and wonder that gets you in the mood for an adventure, and they melt from note to note perfectly, ESPECIALLY the opening theme.

I usually would make a section for the basic layout of the story here, but the beauty of this game is that it gives you no story, which leaves you to do everything that YOU want to do.

This game would be perfect in my opinion if all the problems with the controls where fixed and there were maybe a few more dungeons, but everytime that I load up this game, I hear that theme and I makes me calm and ready for any challenges that face my way.
So in conclusion, my final rating for this game is a 6/10, probably 10/10 if not for so many problems.

reviewText:
Morrowind is really a masterpiece RPG, one I've played since I got a copy in 2003. It can be difficult at early levels, but honestly, there's nothing too hard about it. A lot of problems that new players find have simple solutions.
Think movement is too slow? Go with Sign of the Steed.
Can't hit anything? Stop running around near monsters. Slow down. Or pick Sign of the Lady for the +25 Agility, or Warrior for the all-around attack boost. Or make sure your racial weapon bonuses and class bonuses line up with your weapon.
Still having trouble with Stamina? Amulets of Stamina are pretty easy to find once you get to Balmora. Just visit the enchanter in the Mage's Guild, or spend some pocket change hopping between the guilds until you find one.
Is money getting you down? Sell everything you find, do some quests. You'll have more than you know what to do with soon enough.
Game crashes a lot? Save often, or get patches. Actually, do both. The Morrowind Code Patch is amazing, and saving often, in different slots, never hurt anyone.

Can't fight off chains of Dark Brotherhood Assassins who keep interrupting your rest? You got me there. Those guys are pretty tough. Don't wander so far from civilization that you can't take some trips to Ebonheart after your first attack, I guess.

Enemies to watch out for early on include ghosts (you will want silver or magic weapons for them), that mage in the newbie cave (he might kill you in 1 hit, often takes 2), and pretty much any enemies in dungeons that aren't in the starter area. Not all dungeons are like this, but save before you check out each one.

Once you get the hang of the game, you'll find that everything you do can be OP if you play your cards right. I've walked into Daedric ruins at level 2/3 and killed some of the high-level NPCs in there for really nice loot, like Ebony and Orcish armor. It took a lot of potions, but it was worth it. (Hint: save your game before you try some as inherently suicidal as this).

Final advice: save often. Especially if you like jumping.

reviewText:
This game is the ♥♥♥♥ man, half of my childhood right here. Yes, this review is based on nostalgia a bit, but that's okay, since I'd enjoy the game without nostalgia a lot as well

Morrowind is an open world fantasy rpg adventure kind of thing, like skyrim. It's a game in which I never had any clue of what to do, but simply enjoyed screwing around. You can choose your own adventure; do you want to do missions? Be a thief and ♥♥♥♥ the system? Be a mage and kill everyone? In Morrowind it's fairly difficult to find out what to do, to be honest. I've found myself wandering around a whole lot, never following the questline due to difficulty (and my lack of english skills back when I was 9, when I mostly played this) so I went the easy way and cheated my way to the top. I became a mage that could kill literally the entire world in 1 spell (quite boring) but then decided to start over and become a skilled marksman and steal whatever I could, trying not to get caught but when I did, I killed the whole town.

Morrowind is an extremely unforgiving game; you steal a loaf of bread and everyone in the world tries to kill you. It stimulates good behaviour but doesn't prevent you from breaking the rules. Morrowind is one of the best games I've ever played, still up to today, and it will permanently have a spot in my childhood memories.

tl;dr: would recommend, 8/10 due to graphics and engine limitations

reviewText: I've heard a lot of people rant and rave about this game. Personally, I started the Elder Scrolls series at Oblivion and then went to Skyrim. I tried Morrowind after that and just couldn't get into it. Then, I got into a situation with work where I had a lot of time where I couldn't be with any of my friends when I got any time off. Fortunately, I had my PC with me. That's when I tried to just grind out Morrowind--mostly for the lore. I'm glad I did. Once I got past the first five levels or so, the game became exponentially more enjoyable. On all of my other start ups (I think there were three.), I just couldn't get too far because I would get so frustrated with how bad the combat was and how long it took to get from place to place. If you can get a few levels in and get lucky on finding some decent gear early on, I guarantee you that you'll start to enjoy this game more. If you are hungry for a little Elder Scrolls lore and haven't ever taken the time to try out Morrowind, that is my advice to you. Grind through the first few levels. It gets better.

reviewText:
This game has an incredibly deep lore. If you want to truly understand the world around you in this game then you'll not be disappointed, it's one of the most expansive stories ever told in any game that I've played.

I will admit, the combat side of things is on something crazy, it's infuriating at times. If you're one to just run around and killing various people/creatures and have no intentions beyond stabby-stabby/shooty-shooty, avoid this game. That doesn't make it a bad game though, in fact it says so much about this game that it can be hailed as one of the best games ever, an icon of its time, despite the fact you can stab some prick in a cave eight times in a row and not damage it in the slightest.

And damn does this game actually take time, you can't get off the boat with the only weapon you have being your ♥♥♥♥♥ and then end up punching an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ with god-like powers just a few hours later. I explored a nearby cave about three hours into the game and got lit up by some necromancer.

Bloody hell I love this game. Invest in it, immerse yourself in its story, love the hilariously weird graphics and never look back.

reviewText: Outlander. Travel east, to Morrowind. The province of Vvardenfell awaits, full of its enigmatic people, the Dunmer (aka Dark Elves), from the Great Houses and the Temple to the nomadic Ashlander Clans, Vvardenfell has much to offer a traveller to its shores. Solstheim, a harsh unforgiving island to the north and Mournhold, capital of Morrowind. There are many things waiting to be discovered. Find out the truth behind ALMSIVI and the Sixth House.\n\nNow dated graphically, but a classic RPG unparalled in scope and size by its more mordern cousins, Oblivion and Skyrim. Not for those who hate reading, however, as there is lots of text dialogue throughout the game. Extremely immersive gameplay, although minor quests can get tedious (as there can be a lot of courier" work). Many hours of gameplay and excellent replay value."

reviewText:
9/10 - This game never gets old.
I'll do a total run through of the game every year or two years and even as the intro scene starts up for the tenth time, and Azura talks of the prophesy (with me reciting it along with her) I feel like I'm coming home to Morrowind after a year away, anticipating meeting familiar faces and returning to Balmora.

I've played Oblivion and Skyrim and in terms of story, Morrowind has the best story centering around you (and not being a sidekick of Sean Bean, or whoever was the main character was in Skyrim (oh, was that me? Whoops couldn't tell) and the story just sucks you in. With a plethora of mods available, you can get textures, models, whole landscapes, lighting, water, and even sounds up to the standard of recently released games. This game really seems timeless.
